PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 402 citizens) and Puplick (from 184 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Disaster Relief Funds, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Boswell (from 184 citizens) and Jones (from 155 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Dioxins
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators at the Senate in the Federal Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully shows that we are gravely concerned about the dangerous substances-dioxins-that are found in the products we purchase and use regularly (products such as tampons, sanitary napkins and baby napkins).
We therefore beseech the Federal Parliament to immediately:
1. Enquire into, and regulate if necessary, the processary, the process used to bleach the paper used in such products as tampons, sanitary napkins and baby napkins, so as to remove all dioxins.
2. To encourage, through either regulation or incentive, manufacturers (and importers) to produce products made without the use of chlorine.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARDSON

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

SPEECH.PARA: STOP RAINFOREST TIMBER IMPORTS
We the undersigned citizens of the Manning Valley in the State of New South Wales do hereby call for: a ban on the importation of tropical rainforest timbers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RICHARDSON

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

SPEECH.PARA: STOP THE BURNING!
INTERNATIONAL A-MIZ-ON DAY APRIL 24 CAMPAIGN FOR THE PRESERVATION OF THE AMAZON FORESTS BY THE COMPANIES OF ``LES MISERABLES'' WORLD WIDE
GOVERNMENT OF AUSTRALIA

We, the undersigned Citizens of Australia call upon our government to take immediate steps to ensure the preservation of the AMAZON RAINFOREST as a wilderness area of global importance for all humanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating the members of the new Opposition front bench on their appointments. If I may say so, they have already achieved a peculiar distinction, being the largest Opposition front bench in the history of Federation and, indeed, probably the largest front bench in the history of Western civilisation. I suppose that there is something to be said for safety in numbers, or, as Mr Peacock put it when discussing the size of his front bench at a press conference on 9 May 1989: `I will bring a capacity to be beholden to none, to be responsible to all and to be obligated to no-one'. Apart from the syntax in the rehearsed press conference, I must say that Mr Peacock speaks like a man with a pimple on his tongue. Let me repeat what he said: `I will bring a capacity to be beholden to no-one, to be responsible to all--
—But you know that it is-

—I would be very quiet if I were Senator Lewis, as somebody might hear him. Mr Peacock said, `I will be responsible to all and I will be obligated to no one'. I would have thought that to be somewhat unlikely. It could have fooled me.
—But you are easily fooled.

—It is early days yet; the honourable senator will keep. I would suspect that the new Opposition Leader would be beholden to two or three people at least-for example, the stars of last Monday's Four Corners program. The extent of the obligation is pretty clear. `Obligation' is the word he uses-`obligated to no one'. As former Leader John Howard said on 17 May, `I just cannot believe that something which the plotters themselves so boastfully spelt out on Monday night; I cannot believe in all my heart that he was not privy to all of that'. It is difficult to resist the conclusion that the recycled Leader of the Opposition, having had six leadership contests and lost five, put the matter in the hands of the Four Corners heroes and said, `You do it this time'. But he has been there before and been turfed out, as Andrew Hay, one of his former colleagues in Melbourne, used to say.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. All senators have received notices from Senator Ray that we are extending our sittings until at least 16 June. If the Government insists upon wasting time I can assure Senator Ray that he will not be getting any more of his legislation through than is absolutely necessary.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Government sought leave to make a statement.

—Does this Government ever refuse the Opposition leave in circumstances like this? The intervention from Senator Walters reminds me of the hero of Gilbert and Sullivan: `In enterprise of martial kind, when there was any fighting he led his regiment from behind-he found it less exciting'. We have a new frontbench but who takes a point of order threatening the Government? It is Senator Walters, sitting on the back bench where she has always been and always will be through every successive change of leadership which takes place in the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to point out to members of the Opposition that there are real dangers in all this stuff. It they want to understand those changes they should see a film called The Naked Gun, which is showing at present. In this film a Los Angeles cop, suspended for shooting six people, says to the mayor, `If you see weirdos in togas stabbing each other to death in the park, well of course you shoot them. How was I to know they were just Shakespearian actors?'. There is a lesson there which the Opposition has to learn in this matter. There are grave dangers of that kind of thing happening to it. Look at the unhappy Jeffrey Kennett in Melbourne today. Do honourable senators remember Jeffrey Kennett, famous for his car telephone conversation with the present Leader of the Opposition? What good did that do to him? The same thing happened to him today. Kennett has been replaced by Brown, whoever he might be, and joins Olsen and the others.

I might get back to the gang of Four Corners for a minute. The Leader of the Opposition described their performance as tasteless. It is scarcely a description used by somebody beholden to no-one. What did the new Leader of the Opposition expect from Mr John Moore, sacked from a Liberal ministry because the Prime Minister of the day found him less than tasteful, his conduct distasteful? Did he expect Mr Wilson Tuckey to be anything other than tasteless? Did he expect Mr Tuckey to be tasteful? Not at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not doing as good as Hawkie.

—Senator Hill is still making rabbit noises, but he should listen for a moment. Did the Leader of the Opposition expect anything tasteful from any of these people? These are the men to whom the new Leader of the Opposition has obligations, and Opposition members know it. Let us look at the composition of this Opposition shadow Ministry.
—Richo is right behind you.

—Of course, and somebody is after the honourable senator's too. Tuckey is in the shadow Cabinet as shadow Minister for housing and small business. John Moore is in the shadow Cabinet as shadow Minister for privatisation. Julian Beale is out of the shadow Cabinet.
—Who wrote this? Look at the 23 per cent overdraft for small business.
—Order, Senator Newman!

—Senator Newman keeps saying 23 per cent. I do not know whether she is talking about her IQ, or what. She has said it 10 times. Of course, Opposition senators do not want to hear who is out. Julian Beale is shadow Minister for employment and training. Is employment and training a priority of this Opposition? Not for the moment. Mr Sharp is shadow Min- ister for land transport and shipping. He is out of the shadow Cabinet. Is land transport and shipping not a priority? Senator Chaney says it is in all his turgid press releases. He is out of the shadow Cabinet. Mr Ruddock--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. He was never in it. The Leader of the Government once again has his facts wrong as he continually does when addressing the Senate. He produces incorrect facts. Mr Sharp was never in the shadow Cabinet. I ask you, Mr President, to ensure that the Minister gives correct facts to the Senate and does not further mislead the Senate.
—There is no point of order.
—I did not say that he was in the shadow Cabinet; I said that he is out of the shadow Cabinet.
—He is not out of it.
—He is. He is in the outer shadow Ministry. Those are the Opposition's priorities.
—You never get your facts right.

—I understand that Opposition members do not really know what has happened to themselves yet, but they will work it out in the next day or two. Mr Ruddock, the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, is not in the shadow Cabinet. He is in the outer shadow Ministry. Is that a priority of this Opposition? At the end of this list is Mr Porter who is Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Opposition. I wonder whether he is expecting the same loyalty in his preselection which Mr Howard got from the Leader of the Opposition.
—Have you got the Victorian branch of the ALP all sewn up?

—Senator Chaney has had his say by leave; it is my turn now. Senator Vanstone is Parliamentary Secretary to Senator Chaney. Is she going to get the loyalty which Mr Howard got from Senator Chaney? Of course not. Why did Senator Chaney announce his intention a year ago of moving from the Senate to the House of Representatives?
—It was not a fair contest. He wanted a bit of a challenge.

—I am grateful for that interjection. There is a bit of that in it. I know that it gets a bit hot for him up here. Let us not kid ourselves, he decided to make the move because he thought that John Howard was a nobody and that Andrew Peacock was a has-been. But, of course, ambition should be made of sterner stuff. Senator Chaney now finds himself like a waitress hovering between two tables as Deputy Leader of the Opposition and Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. He is floating in limbo between the two. He saw an opportunity to get a fat gratuity out of this coup by the gang of Four Corners and he took it. It is nice to have Senator Austin Lewis as shadow Minister for industry. I was worried about him during the week. But it is good to have him back again; we can go on with our argument about misapprehensions.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone again defies every law of political gravity and proves that a stone, as well as a souffle, can rise twice. Senator Chris Puplick-one of the great conspirators-has moved to the right. Like Cassius-and I do not mean Cassius Clay-Senator Puplick has moved to the right and sits on the front bench. There, he will be able to cuddle up with Senator Bishop until he is pushed off his perch at the next election. Senator Boswell-the great interjector-is the great survivor on the front bench. It would not be the same without him. Then, of course, we have the new faces of Senator Alston, Senator Bishop and Senator MacGibbon. We will see about them. I welcome and congratulate the new Opposition front bench. Every politician is entitled to his place in the shade, and they are going to get theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of Senator Chaney's statement.

This country is currently going down the drain economically at the rate of $17 billion a year. I quote from an article, written by David Potts, in yesterday's Australian. Mr Potts, who is not known as a supporter of the Liberal Party, says:

Australia's worst nightmare is now forming: a fall in commodity prices, whose strength has been all that has prevented the current account deficit of the balance of payments soaring past $20 billion . . .
We're getting ominously close to the darkest banana republic days of three years ago.

That is the truth. This country is in really diabolical strife, and all that this Government can think about is playing politics. It will move some immigration motion in the other place; it stands here, playing the part of the comedian. This Government is not governing; this Government has stopped governing. Where are the micro-economic reforms that were supposed to be on the agenda for the third term of the Hawke Government? What has happened to this Government? Senator Walsh is sitting there deathly silent because he knows that under this Government this country is falling into an economic abyss. The only thing that is currently holding it up is commodity prices, yet all that this Government can think of is having Senator Button make a speech in which he tries to make fun of people on this side who are doing a good job. I was delighted to hear Senator Button welcome me back because I know that I have always been able to put him on the back foot, and I will continue to do so.

Interest rates in this country are soaring absolutely beyond control. The only way the Government can maintain the dollar value overseas is by selling off the nation's assets and by maintaining interest rates at extraordinarily high levels. That is this Government's policy-selling off the country and holding interest rates up so that people cannot afford to buy housing, and businessmen cannot afford to borrow money to invest. All that this Government can think of doing is making the kind of speech that Senator Button has just delivered, a speech in the other place censuring the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), and a proposal for a speech about immigration to do with dividing parties, if it is possible to divide parties. We hear nothing about the important decisions. Let me ask Senator Button about his decisions in relation to the waterfront. What is he doing about transport problems? What is he doing about micro-economic reform? Where is the Government's agenda?

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about Richard Alston?

—Let Senator Richardson not worry; Senator Richardson has been caught out with regard to the Antarctic. He has been put right in his place. We understand what has happened to him. We announced our policy in relation to this matter weeks and weeks ago. This Government is in absolute disarray, yet all it can think of is trying to play politics in relation to a forthcoming election. Why do we not see some action and some decisions from this Government? That is what we need, instead of the jokes that the Government is trying to play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is critical of Senator Button's comments. I would have thought that it is a rather cruel world when, after the last week, he cannot have at least 15 minutes fun. When changes are made it is often the case in this chamber that people indulge themselves for a few minutes. Obviously, Senator Lewis wants to prolong this. I was here in September 1987 when we, on the front bench, were subjected to all those sorts of charges. I remember the debate well. We expanded the Ministry to 30. That was met with derision by those opposite. Let me quote Senator Chaney at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we do not believe it is necessary to have 30 Ministers. The expansion of the size of the Ministry is clearly and simply to accommodate the internal political difficulties of the Labor Party . . .
That was Senator Chaney a while ago. Senator Short-who I think still owes me $10 from the game on Saturday; but we can fix that up later-said:
There was no science in expanding the Ministry from 27 to 30. It was sheer, cold, hard-headed politics on the part of factional managers of the Government . . .
Peter Shack in the House of Representatives said:
Was the expansion to bring in people of such talent and ability that only creating three extra places could have allowed it?
He answered:
If our recall is excellent we will remember the grubby and sordid episode that dominated the nation's media . . .
Finally, I will quote Senator Chaney. On 20 April 1988, just 13 months ago, he reminded the Senate:
. . . of our objection to seeing the size of the Ministry increase substantially just to meet the problems that the Government has with respect to keeping its factions in good order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sanctimonious.

—My colleague Senator Collins intervened and used the word `sanctimonious'. We pointed that out at the time. We copped it when those opposite had their fun on us. We did not have to move motions, note the matter and carry on for ever. That is the point about politics. Occasionally one dishes it out and then cops it when it is one's turn. But if Senator Lewis and others are saying that they are happy with the behaviour of those opposite over the last eight days and they think that it can just go unnoticed in this chamber, then they are really kidding themselves. He should look at himself. First, on the Monday, he is approached by his colleagues to go to see Mr Howard and say, `It's all over. It's time to go'. That is what he was asked to do and he went along and did it. We then see him bleeding on the media for the next week saying, `Should I have done it? Should I have stabbed the Leader in the back; should I have not?'.
—Who said that? I never said that.

—That is a sort of a summary of it. I do not think it is an unfair summary. I listened to Senator Lewis on the radio. Maybe he was quoted out of context in the papers but that is what we had. We then had the Four Corners episode in which the so-called pros of the Liberal Party of Australia got on air and said, `We deliberately lied to people'. They then contradicted their Leader. After all, we all know that the press conference of the Leader Opposition (Mr Peacock) on Tuesday was well rehearsed. Paid media consultants were brought in to rehearse Peacock. Every word he said was well rehearsed. He said he was drafted. Mr Moore said, `No, we drew up a document and showed it to him a couple of weeks beforehand'. Who is telling the truth? To some extent all these questions have to be aired.
—Michael Baume.

—That is a very cruel accusation. I have spent a lot of time defending Senator Michael Baume. I deny and I put it on the record that he is not a secret Labor Party agent in the Opposition. Just because he went on Tasmanian talk-back radio and blew the Opposition's tax policy at the last election, does not mean he is a Labor spy. Just because he gave Senator Schacht advice on how to run our next campaign, does not mean that he is a spy. He is not secret ticket No. 1,428 of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. Wherever I could I have defended Senator Michael Baume in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the real reason we are entitled to raise this matter at least in a passing way is that Senator Lewis says there are serious matters to be discussed. I concede that. But what about his credibility and the credibility of his Leader in this chamber? When he speaks on issues are we to believe him? Let me just go through that record. On 30 March, seven weeks ago, after winning preselection for Pearce, Senator Chaney told Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio that his only concern was to gain a senior position in a John Howard led government. Then on 20 April Andrew Peacock told the National Press Club that Senator Chaney `will be an active and effective senior Minister in a Howard government'. When Howard came under pressure on the Victorian preselections, Howard issued a statement which cited Fred Chaney as an example of the diversity in the Party and defended him. Three months ago, on 7 February, Chaney made a speech of loyalty to Howard at their first joint party meeting for the year. He condemned the constant speculation about Howard, he criticised members of parliament who undermined Howard's leadership abilities, and he said that attacks on Howard `give comfort to the enemy'. I wonder whether he was talking about himself. He went on:
To engage in that sort of speculation with journalists is totally counterproductive. What it's doing is falling for the Labor Party line, and really you become a Labor Party stooge if you run it.

There is even more on the record. Six months ago, on 9 November, Senator Chaney attacked the Small Business Association and Hugh Morgan from Western Mining for opening up the leadership issue. He told ABC radio that the current leadership was performing well. When Howard went down in the opinion poll in October 1988, Chaney was the one to attack a Quantum poll used by the Australian Financial Review. He said that it was:
. . . a pathetically obvious attack on John Howard . . . a covert operation to destabilise . . .
Howard commented:
Fred put all of that rather nicely.

I do not think he felt that that was the case on Monday night. I shall not protract proceedings other than to say two other things. What a pathetic operation it must have been. This was the one time I ever felt sorry for John Howard. There he was calling a leader's dinner. Mr Sinclair turned up, as did Mr Lloyd and Tony Eggleton. But who was missing? Chaney, Lewis and Peacock were all missing. Apparently at one stage, rather plaintively, Mr Howard said that he wondered where the rest of the Liberal leadership were. Their real error is this-and where it differed from our side-was that they did not take John Howard front on. It was a covert operation from behind in which he was stabbed in the back. There is no doubt, looking at this front bench and at political reality, that people crossed from one side to the other for the reward of the front bench. I do not think they can deny that. I am not saying that there would not be other motives such as electoral credibility, but I do not think it can be denied that part of the methods and operations was simply to promote people.

Not many people on the Liberal side have come out of this very well. We have been there and we have been through all that, so we cannot crow and we cannot be sanctimonious about it, but we are allowed to reflect on it. Senator Chaney has to live with stabbing John Howard in the back, for whatever motive. I am afraid, Senator Stone, that the old nickname of Red Fred has long gone. We have to think up a new name-perhaps Senator Chicanery. I am a bit of a film buff, and I recall Lon Chaney, man of a thousand faces. Now we have Fred Chaney, man of two faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Senate today Senator Button has decided to indulge himself in a little whimsy about questions of obligation under the new leadership of the Liberal and National parties. I want to respond to him by saying somewhat more about who precisely is obligated to whom in the Australian Labor Party. Let Senator Button remember, for example, the testimony of His Excellency the Governor-General, now sitting out there in the splendid pensioner residence at Yarralumla, having at last come to his just reward on the basis of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)--
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. It is grossly disorderly--

—I would have thought that the conservatives in this place would have been the first people to leap to their feet on this point of order, but it just shows how shallow and transparent their commitments are. It is grossly disorderly for any member of this Parliament to reflect on the position-not the person-of Governor-General, no matter who holds that position. Everyone knows that that is grossly disorderly. The Opposition, in fact, on a number of occasions committed itself-and its past Leader certainly committed himself-by saying that the political controversy surrounding that appointment would end once the appointment had been made. The Opposition broke that promise within 24 hours of making it. But it is grossly disorderly to reflect on that office, Mr President, and I would ask for it to be withdrawn.

—Order! The point of order taken by Senator Collins is correct. I was listening carefully to Senator Puplick. I do not think he was reflecting on the office of the Governor-General at that stage, but I would warn him not to do that in his speech.

—Mr President, far from reflecting upon His Excellency, I intend to draw upon the integrity of His Excellency by quoting what His Excellency has had to say about people sitting immediately in front of Senator Collins at the moment. When His Excellency, as he now is, addressed the South Australian ALP conference in June 1983 on the question of the obligation of Prime Minister Hawke, he had this to say about his intimate dealings with the now Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). Mr Hayden in his speech described conversation with Senator Richardson in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Some weeks later Max Walsh broadcast on his TV program `Sunday' that there was another challenge coming up. About the Tuesday after that I had to ring Graham Richardson about a totally unrelated matter. I got him on the phone, and as soon as he got on, he was defensive, and apologetic, and saying, `Oh, mate, mate, . . .'-everyone's a mate in New South Wales. It's a bit like the mafia presenting me with a bunch of flowers. Anyhow Graham said, `Mate, mate, I know what you are ringing up about, that dreadful programme on Sunday. Max Walsh, oh, he's a dreadful bastard. Look, I've got nothing to do with it, mate, and I want to tell you, mate, we're behind you all the way'.
I said, `Well, Graham, that's not what I rang you up about, but now you've raised it, that's what you said last time there was a challenge'.
And he said, `Oh, mate, mate, this time I've got to tell you the truth; last time we told you a lie.'

These are the sorts of people who now want to talk about the question of obligation. Fancy lying to somebody who is going to be a Governor-General, for heaven's sake! We have now had one speech from the resident film buff opposite, saying what people will see if they go to watch the film The Naked Gun. Frankly, we do not have to watch the film called The Naked Gun if we want to see a small calibre, small bore performance. We can come in here and watch Senator Button any day of the week. He says, `What are we going to do about people who have had taped telephone conversations? Poor old Mr Kennett; poor Mr Peacock'.

We then find the details of Mr Keating's taped car telephone conversation telling the Prime Minister why he is basically fed up with him in exactly the same way as Mr Dawkins is. Mr Dawkins told Mr Hawke that he ought to resign and, what is more, told the press what a great job he had done about the whole thing. The Prime Minister takes his advice from all over the place. He can take it from his old friend, Mick Young. We remember Mick Young with his testimonial dinner on one occasion, when he told everybody the sorts of people he was obligated to in his political career and how marvellous it was. He proposed at one stage that he wanted to thank some fellow by the name of `Willow'. The newspaper report of his speech reads:
`To ``Willow''-Len Wilson-for teaching me how to keep a straight face when I told a lie.'

He was eventually caught up with over the whole of his ministerial shenanigans. Senator Ray has come in here and said, `People cannot take it. What a miserable situation it is, trying to abuse people on the front bench opposite'. Equally, we could run through any of the front bench put up by the Labor Party at the moment. It wants to talk about Senator Chaney. At least Senator Evans is in a position to reflect that when Senator Chaney on this occasion stood for preselection for a seat in the lower House, he was able to win it. Senator Evans was not. Senator Evans got creamed when he ran for Jagajaga trying to get out of here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor did Chaney in 1981.

—We have Senator Walsh yabbering away at the moment. We know Senator Walsh has been around this place. He has a piece of paper in his top drawer with his resignation written out on it. It says, `Look, I have had enough. I am tired. I cannot take any more of it. It is altogether too difficult for me to manage.' One of these days, he will be in that frame of mind in which we are so used to seeing him in this chamber late of an evening and will forget exactly what he has done, sign the document and send it off. Somebody will be grateful for the opportunity to accept his resignation.

SPEECH.PARA: A whole raft of people occupy the Government front bench. We are all very sorry for Senator Reynolds and her bad back, and the fact that she is not present at the moment. But we know that Senator Reynolds is on the front bench not because of the number of neurones she can put together but because of the number of chromosomes she has and the necessity in a Labor government for some female representation. Senator Bolkus confessed the other day in the Adelaide Advertiser that the Australian Labor Party in his State was down the tube and was about to be defeated.

Of course, if we really want to talk about the question of obligations, we can go into the obligations that Senator Richardson has around the place. I would be more than delighted to take the opportunity to reflect once again in terms of standards on the Government front bench and to talk to honourable senators opposite about Peter Baldwin; to talk to them about Enmore; to talk to them about Tommy Domican; to talk to them about Joe Meissner; to talk to them about the Pavilion in the Park restaurant and Nugan Hand and the money that changed hands; to talk to them about Virginia Perger; to talk to them about Harris-Daishowa and the Loosley conviction; to talk to them about Laurie Brereton and the Botany scandal and the Walker cover-up; to talk to them about Warren Anderson; to talk to them about Rex Jackson; to talk to them about the self confessions around the place; to read out the extracts from Tommy Burns's report on how Paul Keating stole the Blaxland preselection; to talk to them about the Liverpool preselection; and to talk to them about their ministerial colleagues Mr Young and Mr Brown. I would more than welcome the opportunity to take them chapter and verse through each of these matters in terms of what are standards of integrity as far as they are concerned, to take them through the question of obligation as far as they are concerned and to take them one by one through all of the points that Senator Button has raised.

Of course, the bottom line is that Senator Button has to manufacture that sort of attack in the Senate because he does not want to debate the issues that are of real concern to the people of Australia: the issues of housing interest rates, debt, falling living standards, pressures on our families, the decline in the education system, the perversion of the health system and the absolute degree of incompetence that this Government has manifested over the last couple of months. Honourable senators opposite know that, even with the temporary difficulties that might have occurred in the Opposition recently, all of the latest public opinion polls clearly indicate that whenever the Government wants to go to an election we will meet it and defeat it. They know that full well.

All of the efforts that Senator Schacht and his friends can put together to try to gain some degree of prominence and notoriety around the place will do them no good because, at the end of the day, they know that the Opposition, in terms of policies, leadership and the personnel on its front bench, is capable of matching the Government in any electoral context at any time and sending it as quickly as possible to defeat.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray wishes to raise questions about Tasmania and the sudden conversion of members of the Australian Labor Party to all sorts of electoral strategies regarding the environment. The fact is that Mr Keating now wants to be seen in cartoons around the country not so much as the grim reaper but as a sort of supernumerary penguin so far as the Antarctic is concerned. These are the sorts of things that this Government will continue to raise.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate today, having been brought on the way it has been by Senator Button, is a simple indication of the extent to which this Government is absolutely terrified of the capacity of the Australian people to make a judgment on its economic failures and mismanagement. Of course the Government does not want to face Question Time; of course it does not want to face issues about the economy; and of course it does not want to face debate on the Appropriation Bills. It knows full well that when those issues are debated and the opportunity is given to the people of Australia to pronounce judgment upon it for its economic and administrative incompetence, they will do so in the best possible way at the ballot box by tossing out this miserable and discredited government of failures and no-hopers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to pursue policies which will address the twin evils of a dangerous level of foreign debt and declining living standards, leading to a growing loss of control over the future of Australia, and notes:

(a) that in the first 10 months of 1988-89 Australia's deficit on the current account of our balance of payments has already reached $14 040 million, compared with the Treasurer's (Mr Keating) budget forecast of $9,500 million for the year as a whole, and that many forecasters are now predicting a total 1988-89 deficit as high as $17,000 million;

(b) that these external deficits can only be financed either through further borrowings by Australians from foreigners or by further sales of Australian land or other assets to foreign owners, and there is growing public unease at the speed and extent of the continuing growth in foreign ownership of Australian land and other assets;

(c) that at end-December 1988 Australians' net foreign debt was already $95.5 billion, and that since then that figure will have been significantly increased both by the succession of monthly external deficits and by the now significant fall in the value of our dollar;

(d) that the consumer price index (CPI) has risen by 6.9 per cent during the 12 months ended in the recent March quarter 1989, that this inflation rate is now expected to increase further in the current June quarter and that in the week ended 20 May 1989, the Treasury forecast that during the 12 months ended in the March quarter 1990 the CPI will rise by a further 6.9 per cent;
(e) that despite the present extremely high level of interest rates, the Treasurer stated at his media conference on 16 May 1989 that, if necessary, he will raise interest rates further;

(f) the sharp cuts imposed by the Government at Premiers Conference and Loans Council meetings held during the week ended 20 May 1989, in the funds available to the States in 1989-90, and condemns the Government for its expressed intention to refrain from applying the same budgetary medicine to the spending excesses of its own Ministers in Canberra; and

(g) the utter failure of the so-called Accord between the Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions to promote the productivity increases which will provide real wage increases, with consequences for living standards, our international competitiveness and the value of the dollar which are plainly evident in the financial markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) acknowledges the important contribution which immigration has made to the economic, social and cultural development of Australia;

(b) recognises that bipartisan support for the dismantlement of the White Australia Policy and the adoption of a non-discriminatory immigration policy have been to the overwhelming national and international benefit of Australia;
(c) welcomes the support now publicly expressed by the newly-elected Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 9 May 1989 for a non-discriminatory and bipartisan immigration policy; and

(d) reaffirms its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

(b) recognises that freedom of the press is one of the fundamental characteristics of any country wishing to enhance its democratic institutions and status; and
(c) hopes that the citizens and leadership of the People's Republic of China can peacefully and successfully achieve their democratic goals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with deep concern that despite the UN Commission on Human Rights' investigation into the deplorable situation in Romania, the destruction of villages and the forced re-location of their inhabitants has already begun;
(b) deplores the lack of condemnation on the part of the Government of the blatant violation of human rights by the Romanian authorities; and

(c) calls on the Government to use every means at its disposal to halt activities by the Romanian authorities related to the destruction of villages in Transylvania, indeed throughout Romania, and to the forced re-location of ethnic minorities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the world-wide destruction of native forests, particularly rainforests, and the devastating and long-term consequences of this destruction;
(b) commends the initiative of rock musician Sting, together with Amazon chief Raoni, in their attempt to draw world attention to the destruction of the rainforests of South America;
(c) urges the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans), and the Australian Government to:
(i) give all possible aid and assistance to Sting in his endeavours to save Amazonian rainforests,
(ii) ban the importation of rainforest timber, and
(iii) act to end the destruction of Australia's own native forests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced on 22 May 1989 that the 11 Chinooks at Amberley are to cease operation as of 1 July 1989 and are to be sold as a cost-saving measure,

(ii) the Chinook helicopters are the only ADF asset capable of lifting the Army's new 155 mm heavy artillery gun and the only means of placing medium artillery and heavy engineering equipment in close support to ground forces, and

(iii) the Chinooks could have their lives extended by 25-30 years with increased capability and halved maintenance costs if they joined the United States military program to upgrade 500 Chinooks at a cost of less than $10 million per helicopter;
(b) recognises that the Chinook helicopters possess an important and irreplaceable capability in supporting ground forces in addition to an important role in civil emergencies; and
(c) condemns the Government for its stupid decision to sacrifice defence capability to budgetary expediency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes-
(a) that a parliamentary anti-abortion group plans to remove Medicare rebates for abortion services;
(b) that such a proposal should not be treated as a `conscience' matter, but as a matter of health and equity, because:
(i) access to medically-safe abortion is one component of a full reproductive health service,
(ii) poor women and their families-already at greater risk of health problems-would have this risk compounded, and
(iii) it would discriminate against the poor;

(c) that international health organisations such as the World Health Organisation, IPPF International Planned Parenthood Federation, and the United Nations Fund for Population Activities have stated that the availability and accessibility of medically-safe legal abortion is a major factor-along with contraceptive methods-in saving the lives of mothers and their babies;
(d) that if abortion services were to be restricted, Australia would not need an extensive immigration program is not a statement on abortion but an expression of racism; and

(e) that Senator Dunn's office has received expressions of concern at any proposals to remove Medicare rebates for abortion services from Women's Electoral Lobby (NSW), Abortion Rights Coalition (NSW), Toleration, and 15 individuals.
