SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement about ministerial arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we debate it?

—Of course. I always give leave if it is wanted, but I would hope for a less vacuous contribution than the last one. I inform the Senate that Senator Reynolds is still incapacitated by a back injury and will be absent from the chamber for the next two weeks. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Reynolds in her capacity as Minister for Local Government or Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should be directed to Senator Ray. Those which would be directed to her in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women should be directed to me.

—I hesitate to put a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate on matters which might be of concern to his constituents, but let me try. Does the Government accept the forecast of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry that home loan interest rates are likely to average around 16 per cent until the middle of next year? Does this mean that the Prime Minister's prediction that rates would drop before the end of the year is now inoperative?

—I have always declined to speculate about interest rates. The forecast of housing interest rates is what it is-a forecast. It is not a firm commitment in terms of what is likely to happen, it is a forecast and nothing more.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that he represents the Prime Minister in this place. The Prime Minister told the people of Australian and the electors of Western Australia in particular that interest rates would drop before the end of the year. Is that statement still operative?
—I have nothing to add to what I said to the first question.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services inform the Senate of the administrative arrangements required by the expansion of the shadow Ministry to a number greater than the current Labor Ministry? What additional entitlements accrue to the Opposition by its decision to have 31 shadow Ministers? What entitlements would flow from a further increase should the former Leader of the Opposition be accommodated in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I think history has passed this question by, so I will be very brief. The situation in terms of travel entitlements is that the shadow ministry is entitled to as much travel allowance per person as the Ministry; that is, if there are 30 Ministers, then 30 shadow Ministers may apply for travel allowance. The difficulty is that we have 31, so someone is going to miss out. It is always possible, of course, that if the former Leader of the Opposition returns we will have two extra positions for which travel allowance will not be made available. Then again, if the three plotters are sacked, there will be one spot over. We on the Government side will not be choosing the shadow Minister who is to miss out. That will be Mr Peacock's task, and the way in which he decides which shadow Minister is not to get the travel allowance will depend on a lot of other factors, which I would love to go into but will not.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the use of a Commonwealth car in a shadow Minister's home city, there is no limitation by the Remuneration Tribunal or by Government policy. Now that we have 31 shadow Ministers, they will all be entitled to that privilege. The estimated cost of additional revenue is $5,000 to $8,000-pretty cheap when we think about it, as $5,000 to $8,000 for an extra vote in the leadership ballot is nothing. The allocation of staff is done on a block basis. The staff will just have to be carved up amongst 31 instead of 30, as has been done in the past. So there is very little additional cost in a direct sense-$5,000 to $8,000. I guess we will find out who the least preferred shadow Minister is, or who will miss out, by the announcement. As I look at the front bench, no one here seems worried. It will probably be a House of Representatives member.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister concerned about the sudden decline in the value of the Australian dollar, or does he see some advantages for his manufacturing constituency as the currency moves down towards his previously expressed preference for a value in the range of US65c to US68c?

—This is not susceptible to an easy answer when there is a floating currency. There are benefits for some in the currency being high. In terms of the international debt, there are benefits in the currency being high. In terms of certain exporters, not just manufacturing exporters but rural exporters as well, there are benefits in the currency being lower. There are some things to be said on each side of that particular equation.
—Are you concerned about it?
—Of course I am concerned about a currency which moves with the degree of volatility, as it has in the last week or two. Anybody would be.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it the policy of the Department of Transport and Communications (DOTAC) to make new television stations transmit on the UHF band? Is it a fact that, by comparison with VHF, UHF equipment is substantially more expensive to buy and to run? Is it not a fact that UHF relies on line of sight for a clear picture whereas VHF can bend around corners? Is it not a fact that Tasmania is the hilliest State and, if flattened out, would be the largest State in Australia? If UHF is foisted upon Tasmanians, a large percentage of us will need to buy UHF capacity and new antennae. Even then, thousands in valley areas will not get a clear picture. Finally, because of the fact that the band crowding problem does not exist and will not arise in Tasmania because there are alternative answers to mainland VHF interference, because UHF is unsuitable to Tasmania's topography and because of the enormous cost of UHF to Tasmanians and to the stations, is DOTAC's policy consistent with the Government's media ownership aggregation policies, with its emphasis on choice and competition? Will the Government, in view of this, arrange for discussions between DOTAC, the stations and, I would suggest, all Tasmanian representatives in the Federal Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information on this matter, stimulated by press reports that have appeared in Tasmania in recent days, suggesting, inaccurately, that existing VHF services will be switching to UHF. The truth of the matter is that that is not the case, that all VHF services will remain on VHF. It is only the new services which it is proposed in due course will be on UHF.
—You are talking about the extensions.
—I am talking about the new ones.
—They are extensions of existing stations.

—I am talking about new services. I am not sure whether that is in the context of services extending the range of reach of existing stations or whether they are new stations. As always, I am prepared to accept Senator Harradine's word on these matters, subject, of course, to later correction if either of us are wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government chose to use UHF frequencies for all new commercial televisions services in Tasmania because this would allow additional services to be provided without disrupting existing services which use VHF channels to serve rural communities. The existing stations would prefer the new extension services to also be on VHF. However, the Department of Transport and Communications advises that providing VHF channels for the new commercial stations in Hobart and Launceston would mean that eight areas outside Hobart and Launceston currently receiving their commercial station on VHF translators would be forced to move to UHF-in other words, robbing Peter to pay Paul. They would in fact lose their only commercial station unless they invested in UHF. Eight areas would lose their only VHF commercial station under the licensees' proposal. Perhaps I could incorporate a list of the areas and the rest of my answer to save the rest of us the burden of listening to it. If that does not cover all the ground that Senator Harradine asked in his question, I will follow it up with a supplementary answer tomorrow. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my answer in Hansard.
These areas total some 40,000 people; that's 40,000 who would lose their only commercial station on VHF. Where is the public interest in that sort of outcome?

Now compare the loss of service for 40,000 country Tasmanians under the proposal being put forward by the owners of the existing channels, ENT and TRICOM, with the Government's proposal where no viewer would lose their existing range of services, whether on VHF or UHF.
The existing commercial stations reportedly claim that it will cost the Tasmanian community $30m to introduce UHF television. It would, in reality, cost but a fraction of that amount.

The decision to use UHF recognises that there may be some extra costs for the television licensees, but the Government's priority is to provide more services for all Tasmanian viewers rather than to protect the commercial interests of the existing operators.

Concerning the claim that many viewers will require new sets, this is totally untrue. No-one will be forced to buy a new TV set. Existing services will remain on existing channels and UHF can be received on most sets now. For those without UHF sets, there are 2 possible ways of receiving UHF. The first is through a video cassette recorder and the second is through the purchase of what is called a ``down-converter'' for about $100.

Finally, in response to the claim that UHF will not provide adequate coverage without additional translators, the Minister can assure Tasmanian viewers that if it requires additional translators to ensure that they receive high quality reception of 2 commercial television stations, that's precisely what we'll seek to have the stations provide.
The Government has no intention of backing away from its commitment to not only increase the number of services but to extend services to all who should be able to receive them.
The Government's program is to provide additional services without disrupting reception of existing services, and that's exactly what will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. By way of preface I, along with all thinking Australians, applaud the Government's decision to protect the Antarctic. What steps will the Government take to establish an Antarctic wilderness park, as has been promised by Prime Minister Hawke? In the meantime, will the Government immediately proclaim the Australian Antarctic Territory as a national park? If not, why not? Does the greening of the Hawke Government regarding the Antarctic extend to the National Estate areas of Australia, including the forests of south-eastern New South Wales? If so, will the Government protect the National Estate forests with the same enthusiasm as has been expressed for the environment of the Antarctic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fairly obvious statement that the Federal Government has always had as its primary objective in the Antarctic the protection of the environment. Our record in that respect in the Antarctic is recognised around the world as being the best. As far as what we will do about a wilderness park is concerned, Senator Evans and the Prime Minister will have the main responsibility for talking to other nations about the possibility of implementing the suggestion with which we are running now. I will do a little of it myself if and when the opportunity arises.

ANSWER.PARA: The main thrust of the question is about whether we will declare a national park now. The answer to that is no. The reason is that we all have to understand that our claim to the Antarctic-which concerns approximately 40 per cent of it-is recognised by only four countries. Given that we are trying to implement a wilderness park proposal-and I think there are almost 40 nations involved in the treaty negotiations-I would have thought that to proclaim a national park in the Australian Antarctic Territory would be seen as pretty provocative action by many of those countries which not only do not recognise our claim but actively dispute all claims. I would not have thought that we would proceed to do such a thing now.

As a matter of practicality, attempting to in any way manage or police a national park would be pretty difficult, given that we have three bases in the Australian Antarctic Territory, all of which are on a strip along the coast. It is a massive territory, more than we would be able to manage here. I doubt very much whether we could have rangers asking people from other nations to do better. I am sure they would get pretty short shrift. Nonetheless, we can attempt to have our proposal for a wilderness park implemented and, if and when the time comes, when Cabinet discusses what the next step is, I would be more than happy to look at a national park concept to see whether it is appropriate.

Another part of the question refers to the south-east forests of New South Wales. We have been actively pursuing a policy for protecting National Estate areas, including the south-east forests. My colleague Senator Cook last week produced a proposal for consideration by the New South Wales Government which, if implemented, would have minimised logging in the National Estate areas to less than 10 per cent, while studies about all of the alternatives in the area were concluded. The New South Wales Government rejected that proposal out of hand. That is a cause of great regret to me and, of course, to Senator Cook. However, we will pursue our policy of excluding from the woodchip licence for Harris-Daishowa logs that are taken from National Estate areas. I hope that the New South Wales Government will, in the very near future, come to its senses. That course could be greatly helped if Senator Puplick, whose silence on the environment is unmatched in this country, would just once ask his Liberal colleague Premier Greiner to do the right thing about one forest. It has never happened yet, but one never knows one's luck in a big city.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of the Hon. Nicholas Biwott, the Minister for Energy in the Kenyan Government. On behalf of all senators I welcome him to Australia and hope that his mission is a success.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FOREST AREAS OF SOUTH-EAST NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question, which follows the comments made by Senator Richardson, to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister presented the New South Wales Government with the Commonwealth proposal to resolve the conflict over logging in the forest areas of south-east New South Wales? What does the proposal entail? Has he received an official, considered reaction to the proposal from the New South Wales Government? Can he respond to the comments on the proposal by the Australian Heritage Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Richardson has just said, on Thursday, 18 May, I presented the New South Wales Government-in the person of Ian Causley, its Minister for Natural Resources-with a proposal that we, the Commonwealth Government, had spent some time working out. It is a proposal that would settle the issues of the south-east forests of New South Wales and would enable me to proceed to issue a woodchip export licence protecting areas of the National Estate that I have been advised by the Heritage Commission and by Senator Richardson require protection. The day before the proposal was presented, my Department met with the New South Wales Forestry Commission to explain its detail, so the technical matters of cutting cycles, location of compartments, and so on, were understood by the New South Wales Government when I met it. The New South Wales Minister rejected the proposal out of hand. I have asked him for a written reply to what was a very full proposal, and I understand that he proposes to provide one. At this stage we have an oral no, but we are awaiting a detailed response. I trust that it will be a response considered by the full New South Wales Government, and not one acted upon peremptorily by one of its Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposal that I presented was based on the criterion that, since the logging in the south-east forest is a sawmill-driven enterprise, the sawmill industry should be protected-enabling the quota requirements for the woodchip mill, as well as the environmental objectives set out, to be met. In preparing the proposal, I was constrained by the limitations placed on me by the Jurasius case decision in the New South Wales Land and Environment Court, which requires an environmental impact statement before areas can be opened for cutting, and by the National Estate recommendations for areas to be protected, requiring me to discover prudent and feasible alternatives if I could, or, if I could not, to limit the amount of cutting in the National Estate.

Senator Richardson has said accurately that my proposal would involve cutting about 9 per cent of the National Estate. The decision was not made lightly; it was made after exhaustive consideration, and I will shortly table details of how I arrived at it. I found no prudent and feasible alternative, given not only the consideration of the National Estate but also the fact that upwards of 700 families are dependent on the industry and that in that region of New South Wales there is an unemployment rate of twice the State average. I had to consider the industry. The plan that I proposed was worked out on the basis of figures supplied by the New South Wales Forestry Commission.

The second part of the proposal was that, over the next 12 months, we conduct a biological study of the National Estate and the national parks in the area. That biological study would be headed by a team that we believe is balanced, and the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales and the New South Wales Forestry Commission would act as a referee panel.

There have been a number of criticisms of the package. The first one, voiced by Causley, was that there were not sufficient resources. The argument there is specious, to say the least. Our proposals were based on his figures. We said that if we were wrong we could make an adjustment, and that we were prepared to enter into joint monitoring with the New South Wales Government to test the validity of our figures. We asked Mr Causley whether he could give us an idea of the magnitude of our error, but he could not do so. In addition, he rejected the two proposals that would enable the accuracy of our proposal to be proven.

His second criticism was that the study of biological properties should be reduced to six months. The original recommendation was that it would take two years. The proposal has reduced that by half-to one year. The scientific efficacy of such a study would be damaged if it were reduced to six months. That is just not feasible. The third criticism is that this is an intrusion into New South Wales rights. It is not; it is a simple exercise by the Commonwealth Government concerning our woodchip export licence. The proposal that I have put forward is rational and reasonable. In some of its key elements it is certainly a compromise, but it would work, and it would settle the issue.

I table for the information of the Senate an analysis of wood resource issues in the context of section 30-obligations-of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The analysis was conducted by my Department for my consideration of prudent and feasible alternatives. I table also the comments made on that analysis by the Australian Heritage Commission-comments which, on balance, I have accepted in part. As I have indicated in my remarks, I have been unable to accept other parts. Consistent with my policy of putting these primary documents on the public record, I now table them. In conclusion, I must say that I agree with what Senator Richardson said in concluding his remarks. I would now like to hear whether Senator Puplick does or does not support Ian Causley's refusal to reach a practical, realistic, rational and logical agreement which would settle this issue. This Parliament sits and waits to hear from Senator Puplick on that very matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. In the light of the Treasurer's belated but welcome recognition that the Government must now look at the role of all arms of economic policy, is it now accepted that the Government will have to make further significant reductions in its own spending in the forthcoming Budget?
—I am a little confused by this question. I thought Senator Puplick was the spokesman for the environment in the shadow Ministry both before and after--
—He doesn't want to talk about that.

—So he is the shadow spokesman for the environment. I thought he might have asked some questions about the environment, especially given Senator Cook's invitation immediately preceding his question to do so.
—Why don't you try to answer the question?

—Don't worry, Senator Chaney, I will answer the question. I can readily understand why Senator Puplick is not anxious to ask any questions about the environment. Even though Senator Puplick is the shadow environmental spokesman, I thought he might have had sufficient interest in fiscal matters, particularly in the outlays side of the Budget, to have noticed that this Government has presided over three years of continuously declining real outlays. In this financial year outlays, as a proportion of gross domestic product, will be lower than they were in any year of the Fraser-Howard Government and next year they will be lower again. So he should not come in here and sanctimoniously lecture this Government about fiscal responsibility when the people that he supported, and still supports-including Mr Peacock-were part of that Government as well, even though he has helped to consign Mr Howard via a real dagger in the back, instead of the plastic dagger that Senator Alston was going to use on Senator Lewis. So he should not come in here and lecture us about fiscal responsibility and ask whether we will address all arms of economic policy. We have done so in the past and we will continue to do so in the future. We have done it with much more discipline than his lot ever displayed or is ever likely to display, particularly now that they have that cream puff back as leader.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When Senator Walsh can disengage himself from his hysteria and rabid behaviour, can he say whether one is simply to take the answer to my previous question as being no?
—I have nothing to add, Mr President.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's reaction to the current student demonstrations in China and the associated calls for democratic reform in that country? What is the Government's advice to Australians presently living in China or visiting there? What implications does the upheaval have for Australia's economic and trading relationship with China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will be aware, on 20 May, just a few days ago, the Chinese Government declared martial law in central Beijing in an attempt to end the massive demonstrations which have been taking place since late April and especially in the past week. Army units took up positions in the suburbs but have not moved further. To date no major clashes have been reported between demonstrators and troops. The central area of the capital remains controlled by the demonstrators and their supporters. The situation remains confused, including the political situation lying behind the conduct of the demonstrations, and the outcome is unclear.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the position of Australians in China, our diplomatic posts have advised that there is no threat to the safety of Australian citizens but Australians are being advised to stay close to their residences and to avoid areas where demonstrators are concentrated. Travellers who intend to visit Beijing should consider postponing their visits until the situation becomes clearer. There has been a consular warning issued to that effect.

So far as Australia's attitude in response to all this is concerned, while the resolution of the affair obviously is an internal matter to be resolved within China, it is Australia's very strong hope that the current crisis can be resolved without violence and with respect for fundamental human rights. We also hope that the situation can be resolved in a manner which will not jeopardise, and indeed will positively enhance, the significant achievements of reform and liberalisation in China that have occurred over the past decade. There has been an opening up of China to the rest of the world. There has been a very great increase in the cooperation of China with the rest of the world, and we hope that these developments will not be prejudiced. China has undergone massive economic change during the past decade of economic reform. There has been steady liberalisation of the environment for foreign investment since 1979. Encouragement of foreign investment has been a major plank of China's investment program, and Australian investment in China has grown steadily and currently stands at around $200m. There is an evident linkage between economic reform and the demands in China for accelerated political change.

To come to the last part of the question, it is obviously the case that the current unrest in China will give rise to some uncertainty in the minds of current and prospective Australian investors in China. But it should be noted that to date there has been no threat whatever to foreigners or to foreign interests. It is certainly our hope, and indeed expectation, that, even if the momentum of reform in China were to be slowed in the immediate short term by current events, the direction of reform will be sustained, thus enhancing opportunities for trade and investment with China by Australia and, indeed, other countries.

The whole situation is being kept under very close monitoring by our embassy in Beijing. It is very difficult to predict with any outcome the course of events over the next few days. I shall keep in as close touch with the situation as I can and advise the Senate if there is any change in the Australian Government's position in reaction to events there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an answer he gave me in November last year when he predicted a current account deficit of about $1 billion or, I think he said, `perhaps a bit more' above the Budget estimate of $9.5 billion. The Minister said at that time that there was no likelihood that, expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), it would be `as much as 4 per cent'. Does the Minister now agree that a deficit figure at least $7 billion more than the Budget estimate is on the cards, that the deficit for the first 10 months of the year has already exceeded 4 per cent of estimated GDP for this year, and that the deficit for the year as a whole will almost certainly exceed 5 per cent of GDP? In view of this continuing current account crisis, coupled now with a tumbling dollar, have we now reached the worst case scenario which the Minister outlined in his Face to Face interview last October and which, as he put it then, would probably require the Government `to do something further on the outlay side of the Budget'?
—In regard to the last part of the question, if I remember correctly, the worst case scenario about which I spoke was one which would arise from a very major adverse movement in the terms of trade.
—It related to the price of the dollar.

—I thought it incorporated that. I do not remember precisely what I included as part of that worst case scenario. In regard to the other part of the question, it is a fact that the current account deficit for the first 10 months of this financial year is in excess of 4 per cent of estimated GDP. I was wrong in October, I think Senator Stone said it was, when I said that I did not believe there was any chance of that happening.
—It was in November.

—Well, I was wrong-just as Senator Stone was wrong at the end of 1987 following the stock market crash when he predicted, speaking ex cathedra, as he normally does on these matters, that there was absolutely no doubt that there would be a global recession in 1988. Everybody makes mistakes. Perhaps we should all be a little less dogmatic or include a few more qualifications when we try to make predictions or forecasts about economic outcomes in general.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister, in part, for his response to my question. But I remind him of the text of his Face to Face interview, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if the current account deficit continued to run at much higher levels than had been anticipated, sooner or later one would expect that would have an effect on the price of the dollar.
The Minister did not refer to the terms of trade. I interpolate that the price of the dollar has fallen by 17 per cent in United States dollar terms since its peak this year. The quote continues:

And if that happened, and depending on how severe it was, the government would respond to that as it has done in the past and that probably would entail doing something further on the outlay side of the budget even though in my opinion that is not the-that is no longer the problem. But the perceptions of the rest of the world I believe would be such that we might have to do something on the expenditure side.

Will the Minister respond to the central part of my question which is: does he now agree that the conditions he then stated have been satisfied and that the Government might now have to do something further on the outlays side of the Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Stone has now read out part of that interview, because apparently I was right about something as well as being wrong about something; that a succession of higher than expected monthly current account deficits has been followed by a fall in the price of the dollar, although a smaller fall in trade weighted index terms than on the United States dollar rate. However, I did say that one followed the other because I do not think one should be too dogmatic about what causes changes in currency. At least, in the short term, the price at which currencies are traded internationally has as much to do with animal spirits as it has to do with underlying economic realities, at least in the short term.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind Senator Stone that we have done something about outlays. As a result of the decisions announced in the April statement and added to at the Premiers Conference, cuts totalling nearly $900m have already been announced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether the Minister has seen a recent newspaper column by Senator Tambling, in which he asserts:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . personal income tax revenue has jumped from $20.8 billion in 1982-83 to an estimated $87.9 billion in 1988-89.

Are these figures correct? If so, how can the Minister account for the increase in personal income tax revenues over this period? Finally, how do personal income tax rates now compare with those in 1982-83?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. It is a most extraordinary piece, assuming that Senator Tambling has been accurately reported. I think the possibility of error is remote because, as I understand it, this is not a report but a column written by Senator Tambling. It is loaded not only with errors of fact, in that the figures quoted are more often wrong than right, but also with gross error of logic and internal inconsistency. For example-I think I can say that Senator Tambling has written this and has not been reported as saying it-he states that total tax revenue in this financial year will be $82.3 billion. That just happens to be correct or at least it is the estimate for total tax revenue this year. In the very next paragraph he states that personal income tax revenue in this financial year will be $87.9 billion-some $7 billion higher than the estimate for total tax revenue. That is the glaring, logical inconsistency, or internal inconsistency, given that this is, I believe, an article written by Senator Tambling and not a press report. The central allegation that he made is that there has been a massive increase in personal taxation since this Government came to office.
—It has doubled.

—As a proportion of gross domestic product, Senator Lewis, it is correct that there has been a modest increase in taxation; a negligible increase in taxation, as a proportion of GDP, if the present figure is corrected for the Medicare levy, as it should be corrected if one wants a meaningful comparison.

ANSWER.PARA: In making such an assessment, it is necessary to look at the Budget outcomes in both of those years. We all know that the Fraser Government ran a `spend now and tick it up on the deficit' policy. That is the policy that the Fraser Government ran for most of its period in office which, of course, degenerated into complete fiscal irresponsibility in the last year of that Government. The Fraser Government, in its second last year, brought in a prospective Budget deficit, following its removal from office, of 5 per cent of gross domestic product. This year this Government will bring in a surplus of something like 2 per cent of GDP, so it would be remarkable if such a huge turnaround in the Budget outcome of almost 7 percentage points of GDP could have been achieved without at least maintaining the level of personal taxation. As I said, there has been a negligible increase in the level of taxation as a proportion of GDP. The absolute figures of taxation and especially personal income tax have been boosted by the high rates of economic growth which have prevailed over the last six years and the unprecedented growth in employment which continues right up to the present. I was asked by Senator Maguire about the relative rates of income tax. The answer is that, following the 1 July tax cuts, the amount of personal income tax paid by taxpayers, as the Treasurer has already stated, will be less than if the 1983 rate scale had been indexed.

The final point that I want to make is that Senator Tambling is also reported to have said that excise hits the poor hardest, as do indirect taxes in general. That is what the newspaper report said. Some people might dispute that. I think that, as a general statement, it is probably true but there are ways of compensating for it. The real point that I wish to make is that if Senator Tambling believes that, he should send off a letter to the Federal President of the Liberal Party who renewed his calls as recently as nine days ago for the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax and a shift in the taxation mix, or the revenue raising mix, towards indirect taxes.

I do not expect that Mr Elliott will take any notice of Senator Tambling's plea, should he care to make it, on behalf of the poor, because the intention of Mr Elliott's tax policies is to hit the people who have their tinny and pie in the outer at Princes Park while he is sitting in the Elders box with his cronies, guzzling champagne and eating chicken and caviar, all paid for by Elders in the first instance and substantially subsidised by the taxpayer through rorting the Elders account in the second instance. I do not believe that Mr Elliott's fellow Elders-IXL director and about-to-become Liberal Party candidate for the House of Representatives, apparently, will be any more sympathetic to a proposal from Senator Tambling not to hit the poor, not to change the tax mix in a way that hits the poor. Mr McLachlan will be equally unreceptive as Mr Elliott to that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Government accept the forecast of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry that home loan interest rates are likely to average about 16 per cent until the middle of next year, not this year? Does this mean that the Prime Minister's prediction that rates would drop before the end of this year-a promise made at the height of the Western Australian election when the Prime Minister successfully duped the ignorant Western Australians-is in exactly the same inoperative mode as his other famous election promise that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990?

—I was chastised earlier for saying something about this new Opposition front bench. The degree of cohesion in this new Opposition front bench is illustrated by the fact that they cannot even distribute the questions accurately. Senator Chaney has already asked this question.
—And you have not answered it.

—It is all very well to say that I have not answered it, but if there is confusion between a stick-up and something else it is usually likely to be something else. That is what has happened here. It is no good interjecting along those lines. It is very sad that 24 hours, or even one hour, after Senator Chaney announces this glorious new front bench, one gets this sort of mess. It just shows that the level of competence has not improved one iota. Senator Messner would never have asked a question like that!

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of claims that the Child Support Agency (CSA) in Western Australia has been cutting across private arrangements for maintenance? How does the agency get involved in cases where neither party to a marriage dissolution has approached it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the articles in the West Australian about this particular issue. Going to the heart of the issue, I think the Senate needs to be reminded that when the Child Support Agency legislation passed the Senate last year that legislation provided for mechanisms for the collection of maintenance and structures which had to be followed in pursuing the Government's achievement to collect maintenance. Basically, the two requirements were that a person who obtains a maintenance order has to either apply to the agency for the agency to collect the maintenance or opt out of agency collection. The other obligation under the Act was that courts were required to send to the Child Support Agency a copy of all orders they made.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of this and because many lawyers practising in the family law area are still failing to advise clients of their obligation either to apply to the CSA for collection or to opt out, we are in a situation, particularly in Western Australia, where there are a significant number of orders which have not been registered and for which no application has been received. Because of this and because this could lead to major cost on revenue, the Perth Child Support Agency exercised its powers under section 24 (2) of the Child Support Act to register a number of these orders. As a consequence, we have had the problem that Senator Giles refers to. The primary reason for the difficulties that have arisen is that people who are not pensioners and beneficiaries have not been aware of their obligation, and have not complied with that obligation, either to apply for registration or to opt out. As I said, one reason for this is that many lawyers practising in this area are not accurately advising their clients of the effect of the particular legislation.

The other particular problem-and the Government finds it regrettable-is that the first letter from the CSA to the payee in the particular case which Senator Giles referred to did not make it clear that the payee, who was not a pensioner or beneficiary, could simply opt out of CSA collection. The agency has, therefore, modified its procedures to make sure that people are accurately advised of their rights to opt out prior to collection and, in doing so, has rendered an apology to any particular person who has been inconvenienced by the practice that has been followed so far.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Government disagree with Mr Nobby Clark's prediction at the weekend that next month's current account deficit is likely to be close to $2 billion, especially having regard to such lumpy items as aircraft importations? I refer to the Treasurer's admission that, because of the current account deficit disaster, Australia will have to improve its trade surplus by another $2 billion next year just to meet its debt obligations. In view of the Government's belated conversion to the need to employ all four arms of economic policy, what approach does the Government propose to take to meet the increased level of debt service, other than its current policy of drift?
—I thought that the Treasurer had made his views quite clear about the statements made by Mr Nobby Clark at the weekend.
—Will it be $2 billion or not?

—Whether he agrees with the figure or not, I do not know. It is certainly recognised by the Government that in next month's current account figure there will be a large aircraft component which will force that up. That is a matter of common knowledge. In so far as the respective arms of Government policy are concerned, that matter is currently subject to Government consideration and will be the subject of an announcement at the appropriate time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to an answer he gave in this place to a question from Senator Powell regarding the importation of used cars into Western Australia. In that answer he noted that allegations about the safety of such vehicles, the supply of spare parts and insurance were a real concern to consumers and that he would ask the Trade Practices Commission to look into the matter. Are the investigations of the Trade Practices Commission now complete? Is the Minister in a position to advise the Senate of the result of these investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering this question, I would like to place on record the active and continuing interest that Senator McKiernan has shown in this issue. As he mentions, the background to this issue is that there have been a number of allegations relating to the safety of, the availability of spare parts for, as well as insurance and finance questions regarding a large number of imported Japanese used cars which are still being imported through Western Australia. As a consequence of those problems, I asked the Trade Practices Commission to look at the issues involved in this and to report back to me. The Trade Practices Commission has completed its preliminary report and has concluded that there are six problems in this area that are of important concern for consumers. They go to questions of safety, information disclosure, availability of spare parts, servicing, finance and insurance. Therefore, the concerns can be seen to fall within two areas-those relating to safety and those relating to the right of consumers to be adequately informed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission found that there was substantial evidence of potential safety concerns. I am pleased to see that my colleague the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support is to introduce a Bill which will impose an effective national system of compliance to Australian vehicle design rules for imported cars. That initiative is very much in line with the Trade Practices Commission's recommendations and with the recent decision of the Australian Transport Advisory Council. It should be stressed at this particular stage that most players in the field see the need for a strong national uniform approach to matters such as these and do so because it is seen that these problems do not necessarily end where State borders start and finish.

The other problem that needs to be addressed arising out of the Trade Practices Commission report is that of information disclosure. The Trade Practices Commission has identified two major areas that we need to address in this area. One is that, even after compliance with Australian vehicle design regulations, there will still be significant differences in the mechanical make-up of imported vehicles as opposed to domestic models. So there will be a number of disclosure problems that we will have to address there. There is also the problem of the existing large store of cars that have already been imported into Australia.

The disclosure problems relate to four specific areas. Insurance, finance and repairs are three of those areas. The fourth is the question of the adequacy of supplies of spare parts, which is a particular issue for which there is specific provision in the Trade Practices Act. Basically, once we put aside the problem of safety which should be addressed by the Bill to be introduced by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, we are talking about the need for fair trading in this particular area to ensure that consumers do have adequate access to information to alert them to the fact that there are major differences between these cars and domestic models.

To that effect, the Commission has recommended that further work between the parties be undertaken to ensure that there is adequate disclosure and that consumers are made aware of the differences when considering the purchase of an imported used car. Overall, I think that, between the actions of the Minister for Transport and Communications, the Trade Practices Commission and me, we have made a comprehensive response to this problem, and I would like at this stage to put on record my appreciation of the Trade Practices Commission in providing a very useful and constructive basis for governments to take further action.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister intend to condemn Premier Dowding for his decision yesterday to raise State taxes and charges-including a 36 per cent increase in fuel levy-in the aftermath of last week's Premiers Conference, as he did the New South Wales Government earlier this month? Is Mr Dowding also taking, to quote from the Minister's attack on Mr Greiner, `the easy way out' in `not taking a rigorous approach to expenditure and by raising taxes'? Does he support the suggestion of his Federal Western Australian colleague Mr Gear that any increases in State taxes and charges above the inflation rate after a Premiers Conference should be cut from the State's allocation from the Commonwealth?

—The critical fact conveniently omitted from that question is that Mr Greiner promised in his election campaign only 14 months ago that the New South Wales Government would return for road construction every cent of the money collected by the State Government as a fuel tax. Had he honoured that promise there would have been something like $180m or $200m in extra State funds available for road construction. Mr Greiner welshed on that promise and said, `We will impose an additional tax to fund extra expenditure on roads'. No such situation applied in Western Australia.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does that mean that the Minister intends to make fish of one and fowl of the other? Does it further mean that the Federal Government intends to make the States make the hard decisions which it is clearly not willing to make to repair this economy?

—That sort of rhetoric might go down pretty well with Urbanchich and the rest of the uglies, but in asking a question that tries to compare fishes and fowl, to use Senator Bishop's term, that is exactly what Senator Bishop did. She omitted the critical fact of Mr Greiner's promise that he would return every dollar raised in fuel tax for New South Wales-a promise upon which he welshed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. According to press reports in Japan quoting sources in the Japanese Defence Agency, the United States Navy is putting together the largest scale defence exercise in history in the North Pacific in September and October this year, involving six aircraft-carriers, two infantry divisions and 1,200 tactical aircraft. I ask the Minister whether the Australian Government is aware of the planning for this exercise, which involves all its regional allies, including Japan, the Republic of Korea and the Philippines. If so, has the Australian Government suggested to the United States that this is hardly an appropriate exercise in light of the proposals for naval arms control in the North Pacific put forward last year by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden? Finally, I ask whether there is any accuracy in the report by Agence France Presse in Tokyo on 20 March this year that Australia has also been asked to join the exercise, known as PACEX, which will span both the Pacific and Indian Oceans and include land, air and naval forces. If the Australian Defence Force (ADF) has not been invited actively to participate, has Australia been invited to send observers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Government is aware of an exercise involving the United States and a number of our regional allies which I think is called PACEX. As far as I know, we have not talked to the United States about that; nor, so far as I am aware, have we spoken to our other regional allies, the Australian Government's view being that our allies are entitled to do what they will. In respect of press reports, one should always be a bit wary of believing such reports. The ADF has not been invited to participate in the exercise and will not be participating, nor has it been invited to send observers, and it will not be.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to reported comments that the Department of Defence will scrap the Chinook helicopter in favour of the Black Hawk. Is the Minister aware that in recent flooding in south-west Queensland, and during fierce storms off the Queensland coast, the Chinook was used to provide invaluable service to the community, that this helicopter was the only one capable of withstanding the gale force winds in order to rescue people stranded at sea, and that almost 1,000 bales of fodder were dropped daily by the helicopter for livestock trapped in the floods? Although I accept that this is not the primary role of the Chinook helicopter, I ask the Minister: What consideration was given to its effectiveness in supporting the community during such times when the decision was made to scrap the helicopter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is very similar to a question I took on notice from Senator Sheil in the last couple of days of the previous two-week sitting. I hope that in answering Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question I shall cover Senator Sheil's concerns. There are presently 11 Chinooks in the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF), and they are based at Amberley in Queensland. While the Chinook has performed creditably during its 16 years of service, it has reached a stage in its service life where operating costs are increasing dramatically, and to maintain the helicopter in service would require a major upgrade. The Department of Defence has considered all of the options involved in retaining the Chinook in service but, on balance, and in considering the capability of the Army's new Black Hawk helicopter, the ADF decided that it can neither afford nor justify the retention of the Chinook.

ANSWER.PARA: The majority of the Chinook's tasks can be performed by the Black Hawk or by other elements of the force in being. Obviously it is a difficult decision but, in view of the need for the defence forces to exercise financial restraint to allow the development of other higher priorities, the retention of the Chinook can be neither afforded nor justified. The Chinook costs about $7,080 per hour to operate, and the serviceability rates, despite the best efforts of the RAAF, have been very low. Australia's new battlefield helicopter, the Black Hawk, which will provide improved troop mobility, costs only $2,390 per hour to operate, which is a greatly reduced cost in terms of what the Chinook does now. Of course, any upgrade on the Chinook from a C model to a D model-that is what we are talking about here-would cost of the order of $200m. That just cannot sensibly be done.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen raised the question of rescues and Senator Sheil referred to a particular rescue at sea. Obviously, the Chinook's rescue capability could not possibly be the main consideration in the minds of the defence forces when making a decision of this nature. Nonetheless, I will endeavour to discover what the Department intends to do to replace that capability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. My question is prompted by the refusal of the Queensland Government to introduce daylight saving time as other States have done, and the consequent confusion which exists along the eastern seaboard during the summer due to different local times. Is the Minister aware of a comment in the Senate in 1974 by the late Senator Lionel Murphy that the Commonwealth may be able to determine daylight saving time because the Commonwealth has legislative powers over weights and measures? Will the Minister investigate whether the disruption caused by different time settings on Australia's east coast in summer can be overcome by Federal action?
—That is an attack on States rights. It is outrageous.

—No, Senator Boswell. This question of daylight saving is seen as being very important in some parts of Queensland-I hope that the honourable senator recognises that too-and it does have implications for the efficient conduct of industry and commerce in that State relative to other States. I recall the gist of the comments made in 1974 by the late Senator Murphy and I have seen reference to them elsewhere. Certainly, I could not say whether the constitutional proposition, which seems to have been put by Senator Murphy, concerning the Federal Government's powers to legislate in this area is correct or not. I think the question of the different summer time regimes should be one for the States. The onus is clearly on them to work towards a uniform approach. I think even Senator Boswell, who interjected about States rights, would concede, as the shadow Minister for regional development, the desirability of a uniform approach. I guess the best way for this issue to be resolved in Queensland, if it is not going to be resolved by the present Queensland Government, is for there to be a change of government in Queensland. This is something I would warmly welcome at the next election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May I was asked a question by Senator Reid, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. As the response is 1 1/2 foolscap pages in length, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
—The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Before responding to the detail of the Senator's question I should clear up the misapprehension implied in it that Pharmacists are in some way salaried employees of the Government. Pharmacists are in fact self employed professionals who, in respect of the supply of pharmaceutical benefits to the community, received a 25% markup on the cost of goods plus a dispensing fee. Pharmacists do not rely on payments under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for their entire income, most conduct a substantial retail operation in addition to their dispensing activities. The Pharmacy Guild's own figures show that only 35% of Pharmacists' income results from the supply of benefits under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The Pharmacy Guild claims that average pharmacy remuneration has fallen by 14.1% in the past 12 months.

This claim is false. Department of Community Services and Health figures show that in the past five years pharmacy remuneration has risen at a rate more than twice that of Average Weekly Earnings and almost twice the increase in the Consumer Price Index over the same period.
The Guild's claim is based on a selective comparison of chemists' claims processed in the two half year periods ending December 1987 and December 1988.
As the Guild should know the two periods are not comparable, for example:

The first `Safety Net' entitlement period spanned 14 months from 1 November 1986 to 31 December 1987. This enabled some 227,000 more people to qualify for free benefits than in the second `Safety Net' period covering the 1988 calendar year. A larger proportion of non-pensioner prescriptions were therefore subsidised by the Government in the 6 months to December 1987.

The maximum general patient contribution was increased from $10.00 to $11.00 on 1 July 1988, thereby excluding from statistics for the second period all general benefit prescriptions in the $10.00 to $11.00 price range.

There were a number of technical problems in claims processing during December 1988, with the result that a significant number of claims which would normally have been processed in this period were not processed until January 1989.

Additionally the Guild used a number of incorrect base figures, compounded by a simple error in statistical methodology-all serving to inflate their perception of the reduction in pharmacy remuneration.

When these methodological errors are corrected and adjustments are made for some of the other factors I have mentioned, in the 9 months to March 1989 average pharmacy remuneration can be demonstrated to have risen by nearly 3%. This period represents the most recent period for which figures are available and reflects the recovery in payment times following the processing problems in December.

The Government has not, as suggested, singled out pharmacists for a reduction in income. Pharmacy remuneration is determined by an independent tribunal, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and not by the Government.

It was this independent tribunal that recently determined, after considering all the relevant facts before it, that the pharmacists' dispensing fee should be reduced by 10 cents per prescription with effect from 1 February 1989.

More importantly however, the Remuneration Tribunal released a report on 26 April 1989 based on a survey of chemists' dispensing costs which implies that the current levels of pharmacy remuneration may be inflated by between 40 cents and $1 per prescription. The Tribunal will be holding a public inquiry to consider the implications of that report on June 2nd.
The Pharmacy Guild along with other interested parties will have an opportunity to present their case at that hearing.

Changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme since January 1988 have affected pharmacy incomes. On the other hand however the Remuneration Tribunal considered that income lost from both Government decisions and cost increases was more than offset by windfall gains achieved through the 25% markup on rapidly rising drug prices. The Tribunal considered all these factors before deciding to reduce the dispensing fee component of pharmacy remuneration with effect from 1 February 1989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also on 5 May I was asked a question by Senator Powell on the subject of the alleged lack of support by the child-care industry. I have a long answer to that question. Rather than read it, I again seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The vast majority of service providers have implemented the new fee relief arrangements and it is a gross overstatement to say that there is a lack of support by the child care industry.

Of course any new procedures will have some initial teething problems. The Ministers for Community Services and Health and Social Security are aware of some of the initial administrative issues which have arisen and officers from their two departments are working closely to resolve these. The Department of Social Security will shortly commence an implementation review and a sample of service providers will have the opportunity to report on any implementation problems they are experiencing.

The honourable senator's question implies that the Commonwealth has withheld funding from local government on a widespread basis. This is not the case. We are currently aware of only two local government authorities in Victoria which are not referring people seeking fee relief to the Department of Social Security. In breach of the guidelines they are continuing to assess the income of fee relief applicants themselves. Under these circumstances the Department of Community Services and Health has no option than to advise these municipalities that they will not be reimbursed for fee relief paid for clients where income is assessed outside the guidelines.

Staff from the Victorian office of DCSH are in communication with these councils in order to determine their rightful entitlements and a future course of action. Sponsoring organisations will be reimbursed for all fee relief provided to clients properly assessed in accordance with the guidelines.

The decision to have incomes for child care fee relief assessed by DSS was made in recognition of the considerable Commonwealth assistance that may be received by individual families through fee relief. Under the old arrangement entitlement was largely based on self declaration of income and the burden of proof of entitlement rested with service providers. Child care staff have many other responsibilities in working with the families and caring for the children. Accordingly, the government decided to shift responsibility for assessing income to the national DSS network to achieve a consistent approach using uniform and detailed instructions and procedures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is in fact a corrigendum to page 51 of the annual report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority. The corrigendum, which relates to a change in the estimate of the amount of money the Authority has lost because of the pig-headedness of this Government, states:

Although the Treasurer has given his approval pursuant to Section 63e of the Audit Act to the Authority undertaking a certain range of investments, the Authority is only investing its surplus funds in interest bearing deposits with authorised trading banks due to the impracticability of obtaining the prior approval of the Minister.

It is estimated that the loss of income to the Authority during 1987/88 resulting from the inability to invest in a certain range of investments approved by the Treasurer is in the vicinity of $0.4 million.

It is incredible that this Government cannot get its act together enough to allow this Authority to invest along the lines that the Government has approved of. It is a ludicrous waste of money. I wonder whether, when the Government provides this sort of information to us, it might not do us and the Australian people the courtesy of explaining why it is so incompetent that it prevents an authority like this maximising its returns to the benefit of the Australian people. An amount of $400,000 is simply wasted because of this Government's incompetence. A Bill is to come before this place shortly to change the composition of this organisation. It will be interesting to see to what extent the Government will then change the arrangements-as requested, by the way, by the Authority-in terms of approvals for carrying out its financial operations in an effective way, free from the dead hand of the pathetic administration of this Government.

There is a severe limitation of freedom to invest appropriately in line with ministerial approval and the total investment return seems to me to be monumentally inadequate anyway. I think we deserve some sort of explanation. In the annual report we see that something like $32.2m is out on short term deposits and securities, and another $8.5m is in Commonwealth bonds. That is up a bit from the previous year. But the incredible thing is that that earned something like only $4.2m, a return of about 10 per cent. Even Senator Button would recognise that that is a lousy rate of return. Even some of the industries that Senator Button has helped destroy get better results than that.

The reality is that bank stamp bills are getting something like 16 per cent. In other words, if this Authority were given the practical capacity to do what the relevant Minister claims he is allowing it to do-in fact, he is effectively undermining its capacity to do so-it would clearly earn an awful lot more on its $40m-odd of investments and short term deposits of one kind or another than this pretty pathetic reality of about 10 per cent. That is, of course, unless the volume of short term deposits rises and falls throughout the year to a significant degree.

I simply stress that this corrigendum underlines once again the monumental incompetence this Government has displayed in dealing with its authorities. It is either unable to get them to report on time or, when they do report on time, we see the dead hand of incompetence costing the taxpayers of Australia multimillions of dollars.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: RESOLUTIONS OF THE 131ST MEETING OF THE AUSTRALIAN AGRICULTURAL COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to comment only briefly on one or two matters in relation to the 131st meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, which is chaired by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, and comprises all the State agricultural Ministers, their advisers and their directors of agriculture. This Agricultural Council had a very great responsibility to agriculture throughout our nation.

I note with interest that the export of Australian hides and skins is referred to on page 18 of the report. This matter was reported on in the annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation. I note that the Standing Committee and the Minister requested the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council to report further on this matter. If they had bothered to look at the annual report of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, they would have found that some quite remarkable techniques are being used in fellmongering, including laser technology. It is most important to Australia that this is happening because there is a possibility of value-adding about $600m a year to our exports of hides and skins. I believe that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who has just left the chamber, would certainly support this downstreaming of Australia's hides and skins. This is something that should and can be done here. I am pleased to note that the Agricultural Council has taken note of the technology that has been investigated in this matter.

I also wish to refer to the resolution on agricultural and veterinary chemicals, set out on page 21 of the report. If we cast our minds back to earlier this year, or perhaps late last year, when the Australian Democrats were pushing for this inquiry into veterinary chemicals, I think it was said then that the Australian Agricultural Council had quite a role to play. I am very pleased to note that it picked up quite a few of the concerns of people on both sides of the House about the uses of chemicals in agriculture and veterinary services.

When we look through the resolutions we note that the Council endorsed the need to expand the national residue survey. It believed a working party should be set up consisting of representatives of the Australian Agricultural Council, the Veterinary Chemicals Council, the National Farmers Federation, the agricultural and veterinary chemical industry, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Australian Environment Council and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, to further investigate and coordinate the investigations into the use and overuse of some of these chemicals.

The Australian Agricultural Council is concerned about maximum residue levels for the minor use of agricultural chemicals. It has made some very good recommendations on this matter. It was particularly critical of the use of tributyltin-an organic compound used for the anti-fouling of ships. I think it has been brought to the Senate's attention on many occasions. The level of tributyltin in shellfish is causing concern. That is something that I am pleased to see the Council has taken note of. It has also noted chemical residues in wool, a matter that was referred to the Australian Wool Corporation for further report.

Finally, the Council makes one interesting comment. It notes with deep concern the impact of continuing and possibly escalating high interest rate levels on farm incomes and farmers' capacity to pay debt loans. That was stated in February. I wonder what the comments would be now, when we look at our ever increasing high interest rates.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We see yet again another report delivered by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-this time the Report of the Inquiry into the Death of Paul Farmer. Paul Farmer, an Aboriginal Australian, died in an observation cell at Albany Regional Prison on 11 April 1984. He was then 33 years of age. He died from blood loss, having cut his throat with a razor blade which he had concealed in his clothing. He wished to die because for him, life spent largely in prisons no longer had meaning. We are told in this report that he was not proud of the crimes which resulted in his incarceration. The first crime, his only serious crime, involved a sexual assault on an Aboriginal child who was temporarily placed in his care. He committed this offence when his mind was confused by liquor. He was 15 years old at the time and was sentenced to eight years imprisonment in Fremantle prison. Eighteen years lapsed between the time of his first sentence and the time of his death. Thirteen of those years were spent in prison.

We are told in this report that there are lessons to be learnt from Farmer's life and death. These lessons are spelt out in some detail at the end of the report. We are told a lot about Farmer's life and how he first got into trouble through stealing. He stole a tricycle and $4. This was his first offence which he committed when he was about 11 years old. He then committed some other petty crimes, mainly crimes of theft. He stole $2 from some clothing left in a park and he stole a packet of cigarettes. He spent some time at Longmore, a juvenile detention centre in Perth. As I said before, he finally ended up in Fremantle gaol at the age of 15.

The report tells how there was conflict in Farmer's life between the European education system under which he was educated and the traditions and culture of the Aboriginal people which are very different from that system. He found it very difficult to come to grips with the difference between those two systems. Prison officers in Albany gaol, to which he was eventually transferred a couple of years before his death, state that he changed a great deal during his years in prison. In the early days he was regarded as a happy-go-lucky but serious boy who was interested in his studies but he became very bitter towards the end of his life.

There is criticism in this report of the coronial system. The coronial system in Western Australia is given special mention. There is a recommendation that the observations concerning Australian coronial services, which are dealt with in some detail in the interim report by Commissioner Muirhead, should be put into action as soon as possible. The issues mentioned in the conclusion of the report include the imprisonment of juveniles. There are some very important recommendations made in that regard. The issue of suicide prevention in prisons is also dealt with in some detail, as is a section on the mental health care of prisoners. As far as prevention of suicide in custody is concerned, grave concern is expressed in the report about the fact that, although Farmer was searched-and, indeed, strip searched-before being placed in the observation cell, because he had made previous attempts at suicide, he nonetheless managed to retain on his person a razor blade and bootlaces. It is to be hoped that as a result of these inquiries improvements can be made not only to the prison system but also with regard to the circumstances that put so many of our Aboriginal people in gaols.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
