It is astounding that in a period where we are facing deficits of $1.2 billion a month, $1.65 billion a month, somehow it is acceptable if the figure is less than $1.5 billion. What is it that matters? Is it the speed that we go down the tube, or the fact that we are going down the tube altogether?

This country is facing a great crisis. It is facing the need to have a strong government which will administer government policies in a strict and comprehensive way so that the system is not rorted. It needs people who will turn their attention to the real economic plight of the day and not indulge in the sorts of things that the Government has chosen to do in its behaviour today. If Australia is to go into the next century as a strong economic nation, clearly it needs new policies and new direction. It will not get them from this Government. It needs to have a change of government. It needs to have a strong monetary direction. The fact that the Labor Party and the trade union movement are so intertwined will prevent the Government taking the micro-economic measures needed. As we go along the path to oblivion, or to Argentina to use the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), there is a need for the Australian people to be presented with a strong alternative. Name calling and poor tactics are no substitute for the development of policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation and Supply Bills which are now before the Parliament, it is interesting to note the state of the Australian economy at this time. It is a time when we are bedevilled with foreign debt, a situation which worries so many Australians. There is also another issue which probably has a major bearing on the life styles of all Australians at present-people's concern about their declining living standards. When the people of Australia on the one hand have to worry about the major economic issues that seem to bedevil the nation, which is evidenced in the whole area of foreign debt and where it will take the nation, and on the other hand when those people have to attempt to balance and maintain their domestic budgets and households, this reflects very much on family living standards. With a deficit that is predicted in the 1988-89 financial year to be as high as $17,000m, is it any wonder that the Australian community cannot have confidence in this Government? When we are constantly worried about seeing the massive borrowings that are necessary from overseas sources or the sales of Australian land or other assets to foreign owners, of course there is unease at the way in which the economy is being managed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Whenever the monthly or quarterly government statistics hit the deck the press and the media constantly home in on those figures, and this in itself becomes very much a scare tactic in the broad Australian community. It is interest rates that really hurt and hit home. I do not think I need to draw too heavily on the statistics in this area, but it is a fact that an astounding 400,000 Australians have slipped below the poverty line, while more than 500,000 Australians cannot find work. Tragically, 100,000 of these out of work people are teenagers. Basically, the Labor Government has slammed shut the door of opportunity on Australians who want to work harder, want to earn more and want to make life better. We need a change of direction. The fact that the consumer price index has risen by 6.9 per cent during the 12 months ending in March reflects this factor. It reflects on jobs, on poverty and on every Australian family. I refer to families which are seeking to strengthen their family units and to have control over their lives and who wish to be sure that there is a fair go for everyone. Whenever a member of the family is looking for housing or an improvement in lifestyle, the family has to face up to the very high level of interest rates that are constantly before them.

Last week at the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council meeting sharp cuts were imposed by the Government for the coming financial year. That will bring about dramatic changes in the communities in which we live. I know from the point of view of the Northern Territory that this raises very severe concerns. Over the past couple of years of the Hawke Labor Government's subventions to the Northern Territory Government the recurrent funding to that Territory has been reduced by some 17 per cent. That is a very dramatic figure which has a major effect on the day to day lives of every Territorian who is involved in business in one way or another. The fact that the Commonwealth did not give much prominence to the issue at the Loan Council meeting at which it slashed borrowings by Federal government authorities by well in excess of a billion dollars will have an effect on the services to be provided. I certainly hope from the point of view of the Northern Territory that the cuts will not impinge on the Federal Airports Corporation. The confidence that is required in the Northern Territory in terms of the Darwin and Alice Springs airports depends strongly on the funding of that Corporation. I believe that the Government must maintain those sorts of commitments which it has in the broader community.

The perception shown by the statistics is that the Hawke Labor Government has introduced more than 300 taxation measures since coming to office in 1983. Consequently, personal taxes have gone up 107 per cent, company taxes by 133 per cent, and sales tax by 147 per cent. Average weekly earnings and inflation have increased by only 50 per cent over the same period of the Hawke Labor Government. Even with the promises contained in the tax package of 12 April, everybody's real disposable income has fallen dramatically under Labor. For example, a taxpayer on average weekly male earnings with a dependent wife and two dependent children will require an extra $56 a week by July 1990 to restore real disposable income to the March 1983 level. A family with two working adults earning full time average male and female weekly earnings, with two dependent children, will need an extra $71 a week by July 1990 to restore real disposable income to the March 1983 level. It therefore comes as no surprise to learn that the Hawke Labor Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Total tax revenues have increased from $44 billion when Labor came to office six years ago to an estimated $82.3 billion this financial year. Similarly, personal income tax revenue has jumped from $20.8 billion in 1982-83 to an estimated $37.9 billion in 1988-89.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break I had outlined a number of the measures relating to the current Budget provisions of the Government and had highlighted a number of the issues relating to the very high taxes which have been imposed in recent years. It is no wonder that voters are cynical about the tax cuts and about the motives of a Federal government that gives with one hand and takes with the other. Certainly, promises of increased family assistance, pensions and wage rises have failed to compensate people for the erosion of their living standards over the past six years. I contend that the policies of the Hawke Labor Government have introduced a range of new increased and indexed indirect taxes on a host of consumer goods. They have maintained unacceptably high interest rates, especially home interest rates. They have maintained an unacceptably high and uncompetitive inflation rate, despite efforts to fiddle the figures, and have ensured that taxpayers still suffer from tax bracket creep. Indeed, what the Federal Government promised in the April 12 statement to give back pales into insignificance when compared with the taxes, charges and other costs imposed over the past six years. It is interesting to note what the respected consumer magazine Choice stated recently:

SPEECH.PARA: An unfortunate part of our tax system is that in many cases the poor pay a disproportionately high share.

The highest 10 per cent of income earners pay only about half the proportion of their disposable income in excise compared with the lowest 10 per cent of income earners. Excise hits the poor hardest (as to indirect taxes in general).

So much for a Labor government. When looking at the issues of the Appropriation Bills, it is appropriate that we direct our attention to the reports of the various Estimates committees of this Senate. I am a member of Estimates Committee E, which looks into a number of government departments, including the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. Certainly, this issue of the administration of Aboriginal Affairs for the past 12 months has been subject to continual and considerable scrutiny. The two questions that I and a number of other senators have asked continually are: Is the expenditure accountable, and is it efficient? When one measures that accountability and efficiency, I believe there are many issues that need to be properly addressed and taken up continually. I have not been satisfied that Aboriginal Australians can rely with confidence on the Hawke Labor Government. There has not been any real reconciliation or a commitment by the Government to eliminate the disadvantages which prevent Aborigines from enjoying equal opportunity. We want to make sure that the community in which all Australians live is one in which they can feel confident and know that the Government's commitment to finances, in particular, will produce proper outcomes and very good responses.

Once again in the report of Estimates Committee E, which Committee, I remind honourable senators, comprises senators both from the Labor side and from the Opposition, we find very trenchant and severe criticism of both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). If I could make an aside, I was certainly very disappointed that this time, in the preparation of this report, the Government saw fit to replace one member of that Committee purely for the purpose of getting signatures on the report in order to have a majority report. One senator was stacked onto the Committee by the Government in order just to get a report finalised for presentation to this Parliament. The senator who came onto the Committee was not part of the very comprehensive hearings that took place and therefore was not, in my view, in a position to judge the considerable weight of evidence of the hundreds of questions asked across the range of the portfolio. I think that the Government's action, in effect, has forced a reservation to the main report by Senator Michael Baume, Senator Jim Short and me; it has invited natural attention to this particular area and to the high-handed attitude the Labor Government has continually shown in trying to hide behind the actions of Minister Hand.

If one looks at the areas of performance indicators and public awareness programs and in particular, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have pointed out to the Senate so many times, the area of unacquitted grants of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, one sees that once again hundreds of grants-in fact, some 783 grants-worth in excess of $67m remain unacquitted, as was outlined in the Auditor-General's special report to this Parliament. The report also points out that the sheer number of questions that had to be taken on notice by officers of the Aboriginal Development Commission at the hearings reflected not only on the calibre of many of the people seeking to perform in that area but also on the fact that officers of both the DAA and the ADC had effectively been stripped of any effectiveness by the actions of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the last 12 months. The Minister has caused so many senior officers to either resign or retire that the Department and the Commission are unable to administer their work effectively. I hope that these issues are now being addressed by the new administrations in those two organisations. I hope that they in turn will not feel threatened by the legislation, which is still before this Parliament, to create a new Commission, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), which legislation, I hope, will not in any way be pushed or thwarted through this Parliament by the guillotine methods that we have come to expect.

I know that the Australian Democrats share the Opposition's concern in many areas relating to the formulation of that new Commission and acknowledge the necessity, in any change of administration of the Department or the new Commission, to ensure that we get it right. The fact that the Australian Audit Office has found so many serious problems, which problems were highlighted in its recent special report, also needs to be drawn to attention. The fact that the report of Estimates Committee E, which Committee included Labor senators, was prepared to be so strong in pointing up those problems also needs to be taken into account. I highlight the point I was just making by quoting the part of the report which states:

The problems experienced with project evaluation and monitoring which are the core of the Audit Office Report are of continuing relevance to the ADC and must also be considered in the context of the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

That is a warning to the Government, not only from Opposition senators but also from the Labor senators who participated in the preparation of that report, that we are certainly not yet convinced that the new ATSIC proposals will in any way address the very serious issues of maladministration and lack of accountability that have been so evident.

Opposition senators, in their reservation to the report, highlighted the fact that there were many significant issues that needed to be further addressed-in particular, the imposition of staff reductions in DAA and ADC and how this could subsequently affect ATSIC. The effects of these staff reductions were very evident to the Committee. One cannot lose experienced staff without expecting a decline in the standards of administration and management. This has certainly happened. There are many areas that need to be addressed. In particular, I would highlight the operation of the Aboriginal Development Commission Board. The Estimates committees highlighted many issues in late 1988, and a number of those resurfaced in the report six months later. Those issues have been compounded. The fact that the Board itself did not act competently, I think, is of major concern. What concerns me even more is that I believe the Minister, in the last week, has reappointed all of those Commissioners to the Aboriginal Development Commission Board, in spite of the assurance given to this Senate recently by Senator Tate, in answer to a question in this chamber, that Minister Hand would consult widely and comprehensively with the Aboriginal constituency before any replacement positions were made. Obviously, Minister Hand chose to override the very obvious advice given to him by his Senate colleague, Senator Tate, who had heard all of the evidence before the Estimates committees in October last year and this year and was well aware of the very major and significant problems in that area. It concerns me that so many of these issues have been ignored by this Minister.

A number of issues related to the Aboriginal portfolio, I believe, need to be stressed in detail, in particular the duplication of functions that are exercised between the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Similarly, there remains a very serious duplication of functions between Commonwealth and State agencies. It is very obvious to see, particularly from the amounts of money that are dedicated to these projects, that these duplication exercises are wasteful in terms of both finances and staff resources. Areas to do with grant funds have not been properly acquitted and need to be specially addressed. Some 425 Aboriginal organisations throughout Australia are potentially in breach of the statutory requirements of the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act. This is a most serious matter that needs to be addressed by government.

The 300-odd questions that senators raised at the Estimates committee hearings in an effort to establishing something to address the real situation again invite further inquiry. There are plenty of examples of problem areas, such as the duplicated activities that I have just mentioned and the unnecessary overlap despite claims of no duplication between the Aboriginal organisation training undertaken by DAA and training for Aboriginals provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Why cannot this be properly coordinated by one department?

The special audit raised many questions as to whether projects genuinely enabled Aborigines to engage in business enterprises as required by section 24 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act. This important issue, while under study, remains unresolved, as does the equally important issue of grants versus loans for business enterprise projects. Funds distributed for administrative expenses under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act increased significantly in 1987-88 by 457 per cent to $5.78m, and in 1988-89 by 486 per cent to $6.15m. Indeed, the administration costs are the largest outlay in the 1988-89 year. Would this massive increase in funding promotion be transferred to the proposed new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission?

I raised a series of questions related particularly to the operations of the Northern and Central Land Councils, which have in effect become the alternative bureaucracies for advice to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In so many instances Mr Hand has chosen to override the advice given to him by the proficient and experienced officers of his Department and has relied on these land councils which, technically, have very different performance functions under their Act. The fact that the bureaucracies of the land councils have blown out of all proportion is, I believe, the area of major concern.

Whilst there have been many inquiries into the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio in the past year-and all of them have been warranted, as was borne out by the reports tabled in this Parliament-it is now timely that special inquiries also be put through the operations of the Northern and Central Land Councils. Their staffing indicators, their financial responsibilities and their advocacy on behalf of the constituents whom they represent, particularly the traditional Aboriginals in remote parts of Australia, ought to be tested thoroughly and applied to full indicators across every area. There are areas of buffalo royalties, areas of payments for the operation of community stores, areas where funding is not properly getting through and being properly accounted in the areas of the land councils.

Not only should there be special inquiries into their ongoing administration but also the Auditor-General and the auditors of these organisations should be called in to give them a very thorough going over and very thorough attention should be given to every point of detail. They are far exceeding their normal operations. I believe they are not properly representing the Aboriginal constituency which they represent.

There is just a dismal record for so many projects, whether in the departmental area or the ADC. The Government failed to act and to remedy so many of the issues raised in late 1988 in the various reports to this Parliament, which, I believe, are still on the books and still demand and will demand ongoing and close attention. It appears that it is only this Parliament that is prepared to draw those particular areas of disadvantage to attention.

One of the other significant areas relating to the Northern Territory that gave me cause for concern in the questioning was the provision of living areas for Aboriginals on pastoral properties in the Northern Territory. For a number of years there have been extensive negotiations between the Commonwealth Government, the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association on behalf of pastoralists in the Northern Territory. It has been an unhappy saga because the real issue that needs to be addressed is adequate and proper living conditions for Aboriginals in remote parts of Australia. The manner in which this whole area has been handled by the Government and in particular by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is of major concern. I seek leave to table a summary of the negotiations between the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association and the Commonwealth Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs in the period from 1984 to 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Remind me who compiled it.
—The Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association.
—There being no objection, leave is granted.
—I draw to the attention of the Senate some of the important conclusions of that document:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, however, crystal clear that:
There was a deal in June 1984 between the then Minister and the NTCA.
The Commonwealth recognised, and still acknowledges, that the cattlemen did their best to carry out their side of that bargain.
After some delay, the Commonwealth did pass amending legislation to exclude stock routes/reserves from Aboriginal Land claims. But it then failed to proclaim that legislation.
Since the present Minister took office in July 1987, he has walked right away from his predecessor's undertaking.

While he was all the time urging the NTCA to co-operate within the spirit of the original deal, the record shows the Minister was preparing to act in ways completely contrary to that deal, and did so act.

These proposals will, for the first time, allow for the compulsory acquisition of privately held property. What can be done in the Northern Territory in the name of Aboriginal Land Rights can equally be done in other parts of Australia.

The NTCA presents this brief summary of its negotiations to show that it has at all times acted in good faith. The Association has kept to its part of the 1984 agreement. Attempts to represent the Northern Territory Cattlemen, or the Association, as `obstructive' are totally without justification.

It is a very sorry and sad saga that obviously the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, has chosen to participate in an open press debate on this matter at a time when this must be very embarrassing for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and for other Ministers in the Hawke Labor Government. The article a week or so ago in the Australian by a Mr Hoy with regard to Brunette Downs highlighted particular problems at Brunette Downs, but it did not go far enough. The Minister did not address the problems that he knew had been under discussion and under consideration by his Department for some time. There was a total ignorance on his part. As I said, it must seriously embarrass the Hawke Labor Government and its senior Ministers when the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs would invite and promote open, active international participation in such an area. The ideal way to advance Aboriginal causes in Australia and in fact the very plight of Aboriginal people is not to go around playing funny games on issues as serious and as important as this one.

There is a very real need to address major disability and the lack of provision of services for Aboriginal people in remote parts of Australia. There is a need to make sure that the governing legislation that is put in place to enable that to happen properly reflects the views of those Aboriginal people. ATSIC is not the answer in that regard and fails to completely address those issues. It does not have the majority support of Aboriginal people around Australia. Instead, it has attracted the radical emphases of part Aboriginal people, admittedly with social problems, in other parts of Australia. ATSIC does not address the major issues of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio and the intention and guise under which considerable amounts of government funding are being provided for the purposes of Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

This is probably best highlighted by the manner and way in which a Queen's Counsel (QC) was engaged by the Aboriginal Development Commission in order just to counter the arguments and criticisms that had been put forward by the special audit report. The fact that it cost well in excess of $100,000 to engage that QC when the Attorney- General's Department advised, in the details that were given to the Estimates Committee, that it could have done the same task for $3,500, and the fact that Mr Hand's radical mates choose to engage solicitors and lawyers and every other form of help they can from outside, show a complete disregard for the proper process of both Parliament and the Public Service and the way in which these matters should be conducted.

As I said in my remarks just prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, there are so many areas that need to be addressed. As Senator Stone pointed out in a notice of motion that was given earlier today, the declining living standards of all Australian people is the major issue before this Parliament. It is the major issue in this financial debate tonight. People in Australia no longer have confidence in any government at the Federal level, particularly a government led by the Australian Labor Party. They are scared by the borrowing situation and by the statistical information that continually flows out and is forever bad news. They know that their pockets are being hurt all the time, whether through interest rates or the cost of living. They are always worried about how their own State governments will be able to carry out their tasks. I have highlighted the particular issues that relate to the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio because they certainly stand out to me, as a representative of an electorate of which some 25 per cent of the community is Aboriginal. The Government has failed miserably in all its tasks in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is proper when debating Appropriation and Supply Bills to cast a critical eye over the performance of the Government. Since the April economic statement, more and more Australians have realised that the Hawke Labor Government is failing to deliver the goods, both in terms of general economic management and in the administration of such essential areas as health. The whole basis of Labor Government policy is the accord that now holds it captive. Of course the accord was supposedly once the tool by which the Government controlled the economy. That arrangement has been absolutely blown out of the water in recent times. The acceptance of a 6.5 per cent wage demand which on top of tax cuts will have the effect of a 12 per cent wage increase on the economy is quite clear proof of incompetent economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: In the nine years from June 1980, Australian net overseas debt has risen from 6.3 per cent of gross domestic product to more than 30 per cent of GDP. In money terms, it is up from $7 billion net to $100 billion and is increasing at the rate of $50m a day. At the risk of stating the obvious, this Labor Government has been in office for all but the first 2 1/2 years of this period and its current actions have everything to do with political damage control and, quite frankly, nothing at all to do with making Australia internationally competitive, which is the only means of confronting the debt problem. The Hawke Labor Government poses as being responsible managers through cutting expenditure. However, the record has invariably been to cut in areas where it hopes the political pain will be the least without tackling the areas of greatest spending.

Who was surprised that a feature of the April package was a cut in defence spending? Defence is always a popular thing for Labor governments to cut. They have done it before; the present Government has done it consistently while in office and, needless to say, it will do it again. But cuts of $71m in 1988-89 and a further $78m over the following two years are of concern. The assurances that defence hardware programs are still on track can only mean that economies will be made at the expense of operational effectiveness or, in fact, personnel.

This Government does not care that the major problem confronting our armed services is the premature loss of trained personnel, a sector that in 1982 obtained just under 50 per cent of defence expenditure and last year was reduced to 43 per cent. We can thank this Labor Government for little. I suppose, sceptically, we can thank it for the loss of 50,000 service personnel who have resigned since 1983, for a slump in defence funding to a record low of 2.4 per cent of GDP and cuts in allocations to rations that prevent the supply of troops in the field. The latest cuts in defence are based on nothing more than a cynical judgment that there are probably few votes to be lost amongst service personnel and their families. I do not believe that this is desirable action for a responsible government to take.

This Labor Government's actions in the field of health are typical of its general mismanagement and its so-called management strategy-actions to avoid the main problem, save expenditure by attacking the peripheries and at all costs forget about the effect on the welfare of the consumer and the taxpayer. In the 1988 Federal Budget, some $7.3 billion-that is, 68 per cent of the total health budget of $10.8 billion-was spent on medical and hospital services. Less than 11 per cent was allocated to pharmaceuticals. Predictably, this Labor Government is ignoring the major areas of health expenditure that are fuelled by its Medicare policy. Instead, it wages war on pharmacists and pathologists. Of course, that is not to mention the war it continually wages on the consumer of all areas of health. Just ask the many thousands of people in States right across this country who are waiting for so-called elective surgery but cannot get it. They know that war is being waged against them. More are starting to know and understand that the 1.25 per cent Medicare levy is just a figment of the Government's imagination inasmuch as the levy is meant to be paying for a free health system. That levy raises less than one-third of the total cost of health and, of course, it is getting less and less.

For reasons of ideology rather than economic logic, this Labor Government has pursued a very deliberate policy of weakening private health care and discouraging the use of private hospitals. As a result, the queues lengthen for the public hospitals and more Australians wait longer, as I say, for that so-called elective surgery. There are many areas of so-called elective surgery that really are not elective in the true sense. They are areas of surgery that impinge greatly on the well-being of individuals. Resident medical officers at public hospitals are absolutely absurdly overworked, their working between 60 and 90 hours a week being quite normal in Western Australia, and there are reports of regular 57-hour shifts. Of course, if they move to ease this dangerously excessive workload, inevitably the result is even longer delays in surgery.

Late last year, through the Australian Institute of Health, this Labor Government embarked on a propaganda exercise that sought to prove that public hospitals were run more economically than private hospitals. Using the 1985-86 figures, costs per bed-which, I might add, were the most recent available in real terms-were said to be $277 per day for public hospitals and $286 for private hospitals. There is a very small gap there. However, even on those figures the operating cost of $244 for a public hospital bed exceeds the $173 in private hospital bed charges. The figure of $244, however, was obtained by deducting an average operating cost figure of $340 per bed day for Australian public hospitals, and then deducting $96 for outpatient costs. Therefore, if the true outpatient cost is actually less, then public hospital bed costs are much greater than the Government is admitting. These figures also happen to ignore the fact that private hospitals pay sales tax and payroll tax. That would, if applied to public hospitals, add another $15 to public hospital costs. Again, the $20 allocated as capital costs for the public hospital bed is understated and should honestly be placed at $50.

Altogether, I suppose it really becomes quite obvious that hospitals that must balance their books to survive-and that, of course, is restricted to the private hospital system-give far better value for money than those that need merely to persuade health departments to increase their allocation. Of course, those public hospitals that are teaching hospitals fulfil a far wider role, but the policies of this Labor Government mean that they are losing effectiveness through a quite severe narrowing of the mix of cases. For quite some time it has been claimed that in many areas of the public hospital sector this puts at risk the accreditation of interns going through the system, because they simply are not seeing a broad enough case mix. This is because all that public hospitals are really doing is putting out the bushfires as they arise, in preference to looking at all areas of medical care

This whole episode illustrates the fact that this Labor Government would rather play with figures and starve the private hospital sector of support than turn its attention to better management of the public sector, or in fact give people real choice-whereby people do not have to pay twice through having to pay the Medicare levy. The Medicare levy is really only an additional 1 1/4 per cent tax because it is not going to health; it is not covering the costs of health; it is just a figment of the Government's imagination. But as for the Government taking a policy stand that would return real freedom of choice for people to be either privately insured or looked after by the public sector, no, that is all too hard.

This Government also chose to ignore the Royal College of Ophthalmologists, which last December reported that elderly Australians were being priced out of necessary operations for cataracts. Once again, this Government would say that that is purely and simply elective surgery. But how distressing it is for anyone of any age, but particularly the elderly, to be losing one's sight, now that there is an option and, because of the policies of this Government, having virtually to go blind before being able to exercise that option. Interocular lens implant operations that cost between $800 and $1,400 have since August 1987 attracted a rebate of $600, which the Government very neatly reduced from $820. Previously, pensioners could pay the 15 per cent gap or an amount of $20, whichever was the lesser. But now they are being further penalised not only by being unable to get in to have the operation but also by a cost level that is prohibitive to many. The Government has decreed, despite medical evidence, that this operation should take 10 minutes and be cheap to perform when in fact it takes at least an hour. Pensioners pay the price by joining the public hospital waiting lists, as I say, in near if not total blindness.

Standards of health care can only suffer when a government decides that too much is being spent in a particular area and when it then decides to single out certain areas for arbitrary cost cutting, as a diversion from the underlying problems of Medicare. This Labor Government has sought to impose a 6.2 per cent cut in the income of pathologists when the consumer price index has moved 7.3 per cent. In January its reversion to the 1986 scale of pathology rebates, after those imposed in 1988 were found to be invalid, resulted in lower rebates or, in some cases, cancellations. The interim schedule, introduced on 1 November 1988, was first replaced, after an adverse Federal Court finding, with the 1987-88 schedule. The Opposition warned the Government and tried to stop it introducing that scale, but the Government was pigheaded enough to go ahead with it, with the aid, I might say, of the Australian Democrats, who operate from a basis of political envy.

I recall quite clearly Senator Powell, in one of her patronising gobbledegook speeches in this place, asking why pathologists should earn so much money. She said that the Government legislation was sound, reasonable and desirable. But repeatedly Senator Puplick, who is responsible for health issues in the Senate, said that this cannot be so. But it took a Federal Court finding to prove the Opposition correct. After three months the 1986 schedule was reimposed, causing confusion and adding to the administrative costs of pathologists. Once again, the bureaucracy triumphed over the health professionals.

In the April statement we were advised of cuts of between $45m and $49m to be made in pathology services between 1989 and 1992. There can be little confidence now that these changes will necessarily reflect medical realities because, quite frankly, no other changes that have been made to this dreadful system have ever reflected what is accurate. What is even more tragic is that the mental midget Democrats decide to agree with everything that the Government is trying to do in making health care less and less accessible to the public.

Of course, we are now seeing that the pharmacy area is in line for greater cuts. The Government has not been satisfied with cutting back in every other area; it is now continuing to take the scalpel to the pharmacists-$31m in 1989-90, $96m in 1990-91 and $156m in 1991-92. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme-or, I should really say, the pharmacists that administer it-is the latest major scapegoat of the Medicare muddle. Expenditure on pharmacy may be only a small part of health spending, but this Government is missing no opportunity to reduce the incomes of pharmacists and to cut services to the patients who so desperately require the services that they can provide.

In January last year this Labor Government went behind the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal and reduced the wholesale margin from 15 to 10 per cent, a cost that is certain to be transferred to the pharmacists. In August 1988, again as a unilateral action by the Labor Government, the maximum number of drugs per prescription was doubled, not only reducing the income of pharmacists but also taking away their ability to counsel their patients and monitor their dosage. In January the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal reduced professional fees for pharmacists by 10c per prescription. The new drugs pricing policy that was announced in March-with no expense spared, I might add-represents a further erosion in pharmacy incomes through the insistence on the use of cheaper drugs.

This Government does not care one iota about the drug that is most applicable. All it cares about-because the scheme is costing it a squillion dollars due to its mismanagement-is reducing the options to the patient. Here we have an instance where the losers will be greatly disadvantaged, and they will generally be the patients-disrupting accustomed therapy and suffering confusion. If people think that is just a figment of my imagination, they should talk to some of the patients. Aside from that, there is the possibility that generic drugs will not prove an effective substitute in every case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tut, tut!
—Is it not very interesting that we have had a `tut, tut' from Senator Crowley over there, who professes to be a doctor, yet obviously through her--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I take umbrage at the description of Senator Crowley as professing to be a doctor. There is a clear implication that she is not professionally qualified--
—She does profess to be a doctor.
—The implication would be in italics and in inverted commas.
—Would the Minister be gracious enough to direct his comments to me?

—It is quite clear that it was made in a sarcastic tone which would be reproduced in any journal, other than perhaps Hansard, in italics and inverted commas. The fact is that Senator Crowley is a professionally qualified doctor, and I believe the inference that she merely holds herself out to be, but is not, a professionally qualified medical practitioner should be withdrawn.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I suggest, respectfully, to the Minister that he is being oversensitive. In the same way, I might in the course of debate say that Senator Tate professes to be a lawyer but cannot understand the legislation. It in no way indicates that I do not believe he is professionally qualified. It just indicates my surprise that, with his professional qualifications, he is unable to achieve something that we would normally expect of a legal practitioner. In the same way, my colleague has been saying that Senator Crowley, despite her medical qualifications, seems unable to appreciate the points that Senator Knowles is making. In no way is it said in a way that undermines or understates her professional qualifications. In any event, she would probably be better described as a medical practitioner than a doctor, unless I misunderstand her qualifications. I would therefore suggest that what my colleague has been saying is in order and that the Minister might not be quite so sensitive in this debate.

—Within the terms of the Standing Orders, Senator Tate, I am not satisfied that your point of order is to be upheld. I am sure that Senator Knowles will withdraw it if it is abundantly offensive to Senator Crowley.

—I am concerned that Senator Crowley has sat here for a substantial part of my speech to the Senate tonight and has chosen in a very important area, as a medical practitioner, to go, `tut, tut', when she obviously does not understand the problems that patients are experiencing with arbitrary change to generic and cheaper drugs that the Government has imposed on them.

SPEECH.PARA: It says a lot for the priorities of this Labor Government that money can be found for newspaper advertisements, for oversized capsules and for leaflets to doctors and pharmacists-probably far exceeding $100,000 in toto-yet it cannot be found to ensure the best care for the patients of this land. The Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health in this place, the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, had to have three cracks at giving me a very simple answer as to the cost of the distribution of the outsized capsules and as to advising people of the change to generic drugs. He still has not responded in toto to my original question. He still has not included the costs of the pamphlets and the posters. His third attempt said that the cost of the outsized capsules alone was $76,000-a $76,000 waste. No doubt the 5,600 pharmacists, along with the 30,000 doctors who received that big plastic pill, do not appreciate such unnecessary spending projects of that value, as they then pay the price because the Government has reduced their incomes.

The more the pharmacists cater for the disadvantaged and elderly patients, the greater the income loss caused by these Labor Government actions. One such pharmacist lost $3,800 annually through the 5 per cent reduction in wholesale margins; $5,000 through the doubling of maximum quantities of drugs per prescription; and a further $2,550 through the cut in professional fees. Altogether this has amounted to a 14 per cent loss in real income over the last year. If Senator Crowley bothered to go back to her profession, she might see how she likes it. But no, she sits in this place, in the cosy environment of a parliamentary income, and does not now understand or empathise with those in the medical profession and the difficulties they are experiencing.

It is very obvious that this Labor Government and its advisers have decided that Australia has too many community pharmacies and that this kind of across the board bludgeoning is the best way to reduce their numbers. Whilst it can be conceded that some urban areas may have excess pharmacies, any government concerned with the need to provide proper health care through professional pharmacists should realise that closures will affect the actual provision of services. It is significant that, of the nine closures of pharmacies in Western Australian country areas since January 1987, four have resulted in the town in question losing its sole pharmacy. The towns in question were Lake Grace, Three Springs, Morawa, and Beverley-all significant agricultural centres.

This Government is not interested in the fact that the pharmacists head the list of respected professionals, according to the gallup poll of a few weeks ago, with a 76 per cent approval rating. The Government seems intent on diminishing their role as health providers. If the ratio of one pharmacy to 2,900 Australians is considered excessive in comparison to the ratio in Britain or Scandinavia, it is not explained that the comparisons are false. In Britain pharmaceuticals are available from 8,000 dispensing doctors, and a depot structure in Scandinavia means that an individual pharmacy provides service through different outlets. It is worth noting that the number of prescription drugs per capita in Australia is 7.7 each year compared with 11.3 in Italy, 16.6 in the United States of America and 35 in Japan. In relation to gross domestic product, pharmaceutical expenditure in Australia was a dismal 0.39 per cent against an average of 0.67 per cent for major Western countries, including 0.59 per cent for the United States of America, 0.56 per cent for Britain, 0.95 per cent for Italy and 1.16 per cent for Japan in 1983. Per capita expenditure in US dollars showed Australia at $40 compared to an average of $72 for developed nations, including $51 for Britain and $80 for the United States of America.

These statistics are a solid, concrete indication as to how cost effective the PBS has been, in no small measure thanks to Australian pharmacists. Yet the concept of trained health professionals functioning as independent businessmen, receiving a measure of reimbursement from the taxpayer for delivering a major public good, seems too much for this Government to appreciate or recognise. It is concerning to think that there are medical practitioners in the Government who continually choose to ignore that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Crowley.

—That is quite right. If the cost of pharmaceuticals is moving upwards, rather than blame pharmacists this Labor Government should acknowledge that the decline of the dollar adds to the cost of imports, and medically effective drugs can inevitably be expensive. For example, in February we learned of an extremely effective medication for kidney disease, ETO, which for 12 months costs $10,000. There are no easy answers to this problem but this Government, with its use of the authority system to discourage prescriptions of costly but effective drugs, has created a suspicion that cost cutting is more important than the optimum health of the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be emphasised that from 1961 to 1986 pharmaceuticals declined from 22.5 per cent to 8.4 per cent of health expenditure and from 1.22 per cent of GDP to 0.61 per cent. Therefore it is very much a tribute to the efficiency of Australian pharmacists that they are continuing to function under the discriminatory regime imposed upon them by this Labor Government. This is not the first time that I and my colleagues have pointed out the inherent defects of Medicare under non-medical Dr Blewett and the fact that he has employed the essentially diversionary tactic of scapegoating independent health care professionals. This is an evil in itself and the ultimate victim is the health consumer. I look forward to the committee stage of the debate when we can further ask the Minister about some of the outrageous expenditure that he is presiding over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to hearing from the Opposition when its arguments are about the facts and it does not make an attack concerning whether or not I profess to be, am, was or could ever be a doctor. I am quite surprised that Senator Knowles seems to want to make her case by discrediting my professional competence, which she has done on any number of occasions in this place.
—No, you have missed the point.

—I have not missed the point at all. Senator Knowles cannot argue the facts. She tries to shore up her argument by suggesting that I do not understand the changes that the Government is proposing in any of these areas. It would be quite interesting if Senator Knowles had been a doctor, let alone a pharmacist, as she would have been in receipt of any number of large plastic capsules and any number of samples of any sort that the private drug companies have been bombing doctors with. This apparently was no cause for complaint by Senator Knowles for years and years. Apparently, that is legitimate when it concerns private practice but it is not legitimate if it should be attached to a government's serious commitment to providing the necessary information to people who need that information. It is quite interesting that Senator Knowles would be selective in her criticism. Her suggestion, which she has made before, that the use of generic drugs is likely to cause people to get sick or not get well because these drugs are not as effective is absolutely scandalous.
—It is right and you know it.

—I do not know it and I contradict Senator Knowles flatly. I suggest she check out the medical equivalent standards that are required for any generic drug to get a guernsey. It is mischievous in the extreme to try to lead this debate with that false information. There is a short three- letter word for that kind of information. I remind honourable senators that we cannot use it in the Senate about individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Knowles is doing is positively mischievous. If she understood the debate about generic drugs she would know that there was no need for any patient to be interrupted in the course of usual treatment. Very few drug companies refused to cooperate with the Government. Those that did, because they were not minded to cut the costs of their medications, learnt that the Government was very serious about restraining cost expenditure in the area of drugs, in particular to ensure that the cost to individuals, to patients in the community, did not become unmanageable. That is the Government's commitment. Its priority is to ensure that people who are ill and in need of medication can get it at the most reasonable price while still ensuring a viable pharmaceutical industry in this country and the maintenance of adequate service provision by pharmacists. Senator Knowles tells me that four pharmacists closed in 1987 before any of these changes were introduced. I am not quite sure that her case stands. She may have just proven that what is proposed to happen has had no effect on those pharmacies at all. Perhaps the pharmaceutical industry and the pharmacists themselves appreciate that those kinds of rationalisations may have to go on.

It is easy and cheap pool to kick the Government. That is fair enough for an Opposition. I do not mind it kicking the Government. I do not even mind if it has to use the argument that my professional status is forever in doubt. Such arguments are just distractions. They are insufficient and they are not going to persuade people. The hard evidence of what people pay when they go to get their medication is the real stuff, and so is the continuing commitment by earnest, proper and responsible pharmacists to continue to provide the kind of care and service that they do.

I would like to spend the whole of my speech picking up the points that Senator Knowles raised but that could be too distracting in the extreme. I want to turn to a brief resume of the matters raised in Estimates Committee C regarding the appropriations. If I have time at the end of my remarks I might return to some of the points raised by Senator Knowles because I think she made some very inherent contradictions that should usefully be spelt out to the honourable senator. In its last hearings Estimates Committee C, unlike the previous time, proceeded with very little difficulty at all. The one point of some useful debate in the hearings concerned questions directed to the tax administration about the letters sent by the Department of Taxation to people who were either not at the address to which the letter was sent or who had died. I think the Committee was comforted or at least appreciative of the answers provided by the Tax Office that as far as possible those errors had been redressed and were to be avoided in the future. Very little else of difficulty or disputation occurred during the hearings.

Honourable senators would know if they had examined the additional information from Estimates Committee C that two fascinating letters were presented. One was from Mr Ian Castles, the Australian Statistician, to the Committee preceding a number of answers to questions on notice put during the Estimates hearings, and the second was a reply to Mr Castles from the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Evans. I draw honourable senators' attention to these letters for a number of reasons, not the least being that they are fine examples of the art of the good epistle. I hope that the letter writers concerned would appreciate that I do this with the greatest respect and in no way do I wish to draw any kind of criticism or complaint to them, but I suggest that if these correspondents wish to continue their correspondence it might be better in the future to do this directly rather than through the Chair of Estimates Committee C, which kept meeting to decide what ought to be done with these letters. I was very appreciative of them because they are fine examples of the art of the good epistle.

If correspondence continues and is not sent to Estimates Committee C, perhaps the people concerned would like to send me a copy because they are just the sorts of letters one could record in a memoir of `the better letters I have ever seen'. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that, partly because of the difficulty that Estimates Committee C faced in its hearings last year in going through the disputation about the Australian Bureau of Statistics and partly because of the legality of the more recent survey that created some challenge for it. In essence, the difficulties raised during those hearings are now resolved. There is no further dispute about the matters that were essentially the business of Estimates C hearings at that time. I suppose we are seeing correspondence on slightly different matters from those that are of major concern to Estimates C. I say again that they are fine examples of the art of letter writing.

I was interested to read some of the debate on the appropriations legislation that took place in the Senate in November in particular last year. I would like to recall to the Senate's attention a quote from Senator Chaney's speech on the appropriations. On page 2630 of Hansard he is reported as saying:
With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes.

I said to Senator Chaney at that time that it was a remarkable comment. This Government's priorities were obviously clear to Senator Chaney and they were implemented by the Government. Senator Chaney acknowledged that the Government had assisted families at the lowest income scale but he condemned us for having priorities that assisted those on the lowest incomes. I found that remarkable when he said it and I drew attention to it when I made my contribution in the debate. I still find it quite remarkable. As I said then, perhaps Senator Chaney would have praised us if we had helped families at the higher end of the income scale. Further on in the debate on the appropriations, Senator Bjelke-Petersen criticised the Government for its failure to help families. On page 2880, she said:
I am very distressed to see that the average Australian family will gain very little from Mr Keating this year.

It is interesting that none of the honourable senators who at that time were anguishing about what was not happening to families-presumably, apart from families on the lowest incomes-have spoken in this appropriations debate about what has happened to families on the lower and middle incomes. Assistance to those families was announced in the April statement and was implemented on 1 July. I am talking specifically of the change to tax and increases in the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The Government said in its Budget that it would implement those promises, and it has done so. Honourable senators who anguished about this failure in the debate on last year's appropriations apparently have seen fit to overlook the Government's commitments which were addressed in its April statement.

I would like to remind the Senate briefly of some of those achievements. In the family allowance area, for the first three children in any family, the family allowance has been increased to $9 a week and for all children after the third-that is, the fourth fifth, et cetera-the payment will be $12 a week. For all families there has been increased assistance for and on behalf of children. As has been the case for a number of years, since it was introduced by the Opposition when it was in government, that payment, in large part, goes to the mother-certainly to the parent with responsibility for the kiddies. We know from research that the money provided to the mother for children is spent on children.

Increases in payments under the family allowance supplement were also announced in the April statement. The Government in the Budget increased the payment for children between the ages of 0 and 13 from $21 a week to $24 a week, and for children between the ages of 13 and 16 from $28 a week to $31 a week. In the April statement the Government increased that allowance supplement for children between the ages of 13 and 16 by another $3.10. Children between the ages of 13 and 16 are now entitled to a family allowance supplement of $34.10 a week. All of those payments are free of income tax. Any family will acknowledge the incredible benefit those increases will be to them. As I have said, they are paid to the mother and they are spent on children. That is part of the Government's commitment to assisting families.

The Government's priority is to assist families on the lowest income. It had a commitment to extend that assistance to families on higher incomes following the surplus that was delivered in the last Budget. The Government has done so. It has honoured its commitment from the last Budget, yet no Opposition senators come in here and acknowledge that. I suppose that is easy enough to understand; it is better to come in here and ramble across the health portfolio as did Senator Knowles. If one listened to Senator Knowles one would understand that she seems to defend pathologists, pharmacists and doctors. She argues that she is speaking on behalf of the people in the community but, in fact, it is precisely those people that the Government is defending by asking the pathologists and pharmacists to take part in the restructuring and the reduction in costs, particularly government outlays where that is proper, manageable and does not lead to economic disaster in those areas.

If Senator Knowles had followed what had happened in pathology over the last decade or more she would know that pathologists are not among the poor people in this country. In fact, their salaries were a fair shock to many of their medical colleagues. While pathology became automated some 20 years ago, the payment for pathology services has not changed. There was quite clearly room for considerable restraint and moderation in the way fees were paid to pathologists. I do not believe that there has been a disaster in the pathology area as a consequence of those changes. It has not been unreasonable of government to say that it is committed to reasonable restraint in government expenditure and that while the community does not have to pay more, those people who can afford to contribute to restraint-that is, the higher income earners; in this case pathologists-should do so.

I also find it very difficult to listen to Senator Knowles and other Opposition senators who argue endlessly in this place about the outrageous government expenditure. They come in here and criticise us when we make cuts when we honourably, after considerable deliberation, seriously address ways in which government expenditure can be restrained. The Government is bagged for cutting expenditure which seems to be a crime. But, at the same time, the Opposition insists that what we must do is cut expenditure. I do not know what kind of logic Opposition members have or what curious tangle in the back of their brains allows them to argue that way.

I also note for the record that quite often Senator Newman will argue strenuously in this place for increased expenditure in the defence budget. How does she imagine that will line up with the Opposition's commitment to cutting government costs? I suppose that one could allow an increase in defence expenditure if the Opposition would give us any evidence of where it plans to increase expenditure cuts. But we have never heard from the Opposition a serious outline of what its policy will be, nor where it will cut expenditure. We are not told what it would cut if it increased its expenditure under defence. I find the Opposition's arguments insufficient and absolutely full of inherent contradictions. Senator Knowles wandered across the health portfolio with very insufficient analysis. It is easy enough to score points off governments that try to provide information to the people who need it. If anyone should ring up and say, `I have not been advised by the Government of the changes', we could expect the Opposition to be in here nagging us for not making sure that it had been provided with the information. That is a cheap point to score, and a not very persuasive one.

In my comments on the Appropriation Bills I want to deal in particular with the Opposition's complaints about the lack of assistance for families, apart from those on the lowest incomes, and its absolute silence on the April statement and the proposals for extending the benefits to families, particularly under family allowance and the family allowance supplement. I have not heard a word about that. I guess that it is difficult for the Opposition. The Government has honoured its commitment and has increased assistance to families, not only through family allowance and family allowance supplement, but also by way of tax cuts. Families stand to benefit considerably. At the same time the Opposition says that standards of living in this country have been lowered, yet, as I understand its policy, it intends to lower those standards even further by more cutbacks and so on. If it does not intend to lower standards further by cutbacks, presumably it will allow those who can get on to get on and get richer, and those who cannot to go back on the unemployment pile.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about under you?

—Under us, the creation of 1.4 million jobs is a record that stands by itself. It needs no further explanation, but I will elaborate a little on it. Over 1.4 million jobs have been created, and I note that something like 60 per cent of those have gone to women. I am very appreciative of the fact that many women now have some income security by virtue of being employed. The other important thing is that, at the same time, very many of those people are no longer in receipt of the unemployment benefit. So there is a double gain to the Government-a reduction in the outlay on unemployment benefit, and increased revenue from those people now in paid employment and contributing through tax. That is a pattern that certainly all those people much prefer. I hope that that contribution to recovery is acknowledged by the community at large, though presumably it is not acknowledged by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The union movement's contribution, in tightening its belt and contributing, through wage restraint, to the prospect of job creation, is one of the great achievements not only of that movement but of this Government, and it is worthy of our considered acknowledgment. It is a very generous act. The same can be said of pensioners, who also contributed to meeting the challenge that the Government faced in 1986. They suffered a delay in the indexation of their pensions. Any number of superannuants went without 2 per cent over that period-also part of the contribution by people in this country. In his April statement the Treasurer said that the Australian people's contribution to the recovery ought to be acknowledged. I want to place on record my acknowledgment. As the Government said, it was timely at that point to acknowledge that contribution, which, together with the Budget surplus of $5.5 billion-for the first time ever-could be used, in part, to contribute to tax cuts and to the increase in family allowance and family allowance supplement to assist those people who had given this country so much assistance.

Much more could be said about appropriations. I will read with interest and more exactness the report of what Senator Knowles said about health. She made a few other points, not now at the front of my brain, that were contradictory in the extreme-in fact, quite daft. Senator Bishop said that what this country needs is a new government with a new policy. She is wrong in saying that what this country needs is a new government, unless one could call a re-elected Hawke Government a new government-and that would do me. As for tax policy, plans for expenditure restraint, expenditure priorities and tax changes, what we have heard, or not heard, from the Opposition is a continuing monumental silence-can one hear a silence?-over the last few years. The Opposition does not have any coherent policy. There would be no comfort for the community in what it plans to do, let alone in its capacity or ability to manage it. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Appropriation Bills, and inevitably my special interest is in how the Government is finding and spending money in the defence area. Sadly, it is clear once again that the Government expects to do the `loaves and fishes' act with the defence budget. Clearly it has failed in its management of Australia's economy.
—We all know about your views.

—Senator Walsh, who seems to have come alive in the last moment, is very heavily responsible for the failure in that he, having identified 200 programs, has so far been unable to find the knife to wield in order to get the economy back on track. Our external debt, our high inflation, our high interest rates and our low dollar are all clear evidence of how this Government, in its management of the economy, has failed the Australian people. Sadly, that goes to the heart of the problems in respect of the defence budget. Defence funding is static, and although Mr Dibb's recommendation that 3 per cent real growth was necessary to enable the job of defending this country to be done was accepted by the Government when it accepted his report, that recommendation has never been met. Since this Government came to power in 1983 we have had a total real growth of 1.7 per cent in the defence budget, and no real growth whatsoever is planned for the coming financial year. A static budget cannot meet the growing expectations, let alone the vital needs. It is not made of elastic, and the defence of Australia is the poorer as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the expectations and inefficiencies in regard to the defence dollar-where it is being spent, and where it is not being spent effectively. Let me turn first to Namibia. During the hearings of Estimates Committee D it was very clear that the Government has not seen fit to provide any extra funding whatsoever to enable the commitment of the force that has been sent to Namibia by the Australian Government to be met. We have sent 300 engineers as part of the United Nations force in Namibia. We have been prepared to treat them as flag-carriers for the Australian people, doing their bit for the peace of the world. The Government has been very ready to get involved in the media coverage and to take the credit-although, of course, this has been supported on a bipartisan basis-but it has failed to provide the $28m that that commitment is going to entail. The Defence Department expects that that amount will come out of the existing budget for clothing, operations, training and recruitment. The Government has found no extra funds for that force in Namibia. It is disgraceful.

The funding of the Namibian force will therefore be at the expense of tasks that are already expected to be undertaken by the Defence Force in the defence of this nation. It will result in cuts in training and in other operational cuts. When officers were questioned during the Estimates Committee hearings they were unable to tell us where exactly these cuts would be made. Yet we know that this Namibian force has been on the drawing board for 10 years. Surely to goodness, when the decision was finally in the offing and once it was under way, the Government could have told us how the money was going to be provided and where cuts in what the Defence Force is expected to do would be made.

The training and operations votes in the defence budget have already been cut severely over the last year or so. It is quite disgraceful that, when productivity trade-offs are meant to be undertaken in the Defence Force-and if ever there was a nonsense, talking about increased productivity in the context of the Defence Force is one-training and operations were cut in the last year or so in an effort to find the money to pay increased wages. I do not know whether Australians are aware of just what this Government has done in the way of cuts in our defence capacity. There is no other way to describe it. When it is cutting down on the manpower and the training of the people who are there, inevitably the defence of Australia must suffer.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had the nerve to tell those fellows who went off to Namibia that they would all do Australians proud. Of course they will, but it is no thanks to the Government. In passing I just mention that in the last couple of weeks I have had a series of complaints from families of the men who have gone. They say that the Australian Government has not even been able to get mail to the troops or get mail back to the families in under four weeks nor have they been able to get copies of Australian newspapers in under a month of their having been sent from home. That is quite unacceptable. It has very much to do with the fact that the Government was not prepared to send postal specialists, who are in the defence forces, with the force in order to see to their comfort and the conditions of service. Once again, it is typical of this Government's lack of concern for the individuals it expects to fight for us.

I turn next to the decommissioning of equipment. We all know that if the family budget is tight we do not contemplate buying a new car or getting a dishwasher; we make do with washing up or we get the old car fixed up. But of course the Government and often the Defence Department do not think in those terms. Certainly Dr Strangelove, alias the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, does not think in those terms. Even the Prime Minister was on television last night telling us how the Defence Minister likes his toys. That is a major problem that we now face after six years of this Government. The capital equipment program has run ahead at such a rate that it has taken over and gobbled up the defence budget. Little or no attention seems to be given to the need to retain some of our equipment and do better with what we have.

Let me give some examples. Only yesterday the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, announced that the Chinook helicopters would join the ranks of redundant equipment. He said it was an economic decision and that the Government could not afford to upgrade the Chinooks. Let the position be clearly understood. The United States Government considers those helicopters of such vital importance to its defence program that it is prepared to upgrade 500 Chinooks. Australia could have joined its 11 Chinook helicopters onto the tail end of that upgrading program. We would have achieved an extra 25 to 30 years of life for those helicopters for less than $10m per aircraft. It would have halved the maintenance costs that are currently having to be met. It would have increased their capability with stronger transmissions, et cetera. As Mr Beazley said, the Black Hawks would now be doing the job. I do not believe that he is so ignorant. In fact, I think that was a deliberate attempt to mislead. The Black Hawks do not have the same capacity to transport medium or heavy artillery and heavy engineering equipment into an area where the forces need support. The result of that decision-a bad decision on economic and defence terms-is to downgrade our capability and the mobility of our forces.

We have also had Centurion tanks mothballed since 1978 when they were replaced with the German Leopard tanks. At the time it was cheaper to upgrade them. The upgrading cost per tank was in the region of $230,000-odd plus shipping costs from the United Kingdom, or $217,000 with labour costs provided in Australia. Each Leopard tank cost us approximately $540,000. The Leopards are now already outdated. Germany has now developed Leopard II. The replacement costs of those will be enormous. Yet, the Israeli Army, which we regard as an efficient, effective force, is still using more than 1,000 upgraded Centurions. I believe there is still an argument for upgrading. The tanks are useful for training purposes and they are useful for ready expansion of capability in an emergency.

We have recently had the ridiculous situation with the Skyhawk aircraft. We sold them to New Zealand for $28m. New Zealand estimated the package was worth $70m. We are now leasing back the Skyhawks for $6m for Navy anti-missile and anti-aircraft training. Why, for goodness sake, did we sell them? Think again too of the Grumman S2 Tracker aircraft. Nineteen of those were withdrawn in 1984. Sixteen were offered for sale and there were no buyers. They were stripped. One wonders whether they could still be used. When we bought them from America we had to put them together. Surely we could do it again. They are still worth approximately $50m. Again, look at HMAS Yarra. It was decommissioned in 1985. It still had operational capability then. Like the Chinooks, it too was sacrificed for economic reasons: the defence repair and maintenance budget was too limited. The directive at the time was to remove 2,000 billets from the naval establishment.

I now turn to another matter which from time to time comes up when we are considering the appropriations for the Department of Defence; that is, the hoary old problem of the payment of defence accounts. The salaries of those people processing accounts in the Department are over $50m. This is after 189 positions were abolished as a result of the Block Efficiency Scrutiny. Even now, after the changes that took place at that time, there are still seven stages to the account payment process. The Department is rightly worried about it. A pilot scheme has been introduced in South Australia and Victoria for a new accounts system. I, for one, will be keeping a close watch on that.

I also turn to the question of defence procurement. It is a matter which is at present under a cloud. The whole matter of defence procurement and the accounts and tendering system has a number of question marks hanging over it. Project DESINE is the latest example of doubtful and questionable practices in awarding contracts. I remind the Senate that in October 1987 the Australian Federal Police (AFP) estimated that $800m was lost in fraud against the Defence Department. So it is not only a matter of concern but also a matter of vast cost to the nation if these figures estimated by the AFP are correct.

I draw your attention, Madam Acting Deputy President, to the report of Estimates Committee D, which was tabled in the Senate just recently. There is an item on page 2 of the report entitled `Questions on Notice: Outstanding responses'. The report states:
Delays in responding to questions has been the subject of critical comment by a number of Estimates Committees on previous occasions.
The report goes on:

The Committee notes that undertakings have been made by departments to provide outstanding responses before the appropriation Bills are debated in the Committee of the Whole. This situation will be closely monitored by the Committee.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure you would be as horrified as I have been to discover that there are still 120 answers outstanding from the Department of Defence as of now when we are debating the Appropriation Bills. Over 30 of those questions relate to this project DESINE, which has been the subject of public concern. It was also raised and detailed questioning has taken place in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. One has to wonder why it has taken the Department over a month to answer those questions. I have to put the Government on notice that the Opposition is not prepared to support the passage of the defence appropriations while 120 questions remain unanswered.

I also have questions that I think will be of interest to Senator Walsh. I am glad that he is in the chamber because he will be able to take them on board. I wonder whether Senator Walsh has been briefed on Defence's DESINE contracts? Does the Minister's Department have a representative on the defence computer acquisition council? Did the Minister's representative at the acquisition council meeting approve DESINE? If not, what external scrutiny was undertaken to ensure that all costs, as well as benefits, were identified? Does the Minister's Department have any reservations or objections to DESINE and the way it is being implemented? Has the Minister been informed of the additional costs to the taxpayer resulting from the implementation of DESINE? Does the Minister agree that he has some responsibility to ensure that for any acquisition in government the lowest cost effective solution should be sought by open tender? Does Senator Walsh express any concern? No, he ignores the question. Let the Senate take note of the fact that the Minister for Finance is not prepared even to listen to questions of such major importance.

The DESINE matter raises great concerns in the Department of Defence, certainly among uniformed people. They want to know, for example, why they cannot upgrade the equipment they now have in service. The understanding is that existing equipment cannot be upgraded by the previous supplier. They are being told that they must convert to IBM rather than upgrade the existing systems.
