Calculations from within the armed forces suggest that purchases under DESINE will cost the taxpayer at least 47 per cent more than equipment bought previously. Industry observers consider that this figure may well be conservative. It appears that there is an interesting clause in the contract with IBM which says that, in effect, the Department of Defence will buy equipment from IBM unless the delegate is satisfied that the solution offered by `big blue' is inadequate. Is the Department of Defence using the word `exemption' in the correct way, or is IBM being advantaged by the Department's definition? There is a belief in the industry that the Department is using the term `exempt' differently-that is, if a particular piece of equipment is exempt from DESINE it can be supplied by IBM from non-DESINE products. Thus, other suppliers are being kept out in the cold. One asks: since when has IBM been outside the Commonwealth's purchasing rules?

The argument can run that there will be an overall cost advantage in future by having compatible systems purchased under DESINE. There are a number of compelling arguments against that. For instance one has to ask: has a study been conducted which shows the cost advantage of having every system compatible? If not, how does the Government know? If so, can the Senate obtain a copy of that? Certainly the Senate has been kept in the dark on these matters. Many questions are still to be answered about that, quite apart from the 30-odd which the Department has had for more than 30 days and to which it refuses to provide answers to the Senate.

There are numerous other areas where I am concerned about the expenditure of scarce defence dollars. An example that came before the Committee was the question of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) land at Townsville. On the RAAF land was a dog compound used for security for the RAAF base. The Department of Defence handed over that piece of land to the FAC without any recompense of any kind being given to the RAAF. A sum of $600,000 is to be expended in providing a new dog compound on land which the RAAF already has and no compensation whatsoever will go back into the RAAF's budget for land which was given to an organisation which the Commonwealth Government is always telling us operates, and has to operate, on a commercial basis. That is quite unsatisfactory and has not otherwise received the scrutiny of this Parliament. It highlights the value of the Estimates committee processes whereby something as ludicrous as this can be brought to the light of day. There is no way that defence land should be handed over to anybody for free, especially when it is not just a gift of land but will also incur extra expenditure of this nature, let alone that it be handed over to a body which is supposed to operate as a commercial organisation.

We also saw what I believe to be a gross waste of money, although Senator Walsh defended this recently, in the expenditure of $215,000-although he said in the answer he gave in the Senate recently that it was in excess of $100,000. Mr Uhrig was appointed to oversee the transfer to Westpac. Senator Walsh admitted that it was something over $100,000, yet it was $215,000. Senator Walsh either knew it or should have known it. This was the private sector input that was apparently needed to hand over the defence service home loan scheme to Westpac. The Opposition supported the proposal to privatise the scheme. But I find it quite objectionable that for $215,000 we got six months of odd-jobbing by Mr Uhrig. Despite questioning, the Committee was not given any details as to how that money was arrived at. We wanted to know the hours worked and the job that was done and got no details whatsoever. That is not acceptable.

Another peculiar treatment of the defence budget by this Government was revealed in the Defence Housing Authority questioning. The Government has made much political capital in the last couple of years by saying that it has provided $750m to improve housing for defence forces. The situation is that the Government has not given the defence forces $750m. It has provided a loan which is at a commercial rate of interest, currently believed to be about 13.5 per cent. The Department tells us that there will be a supplement for the interest which is being incurred by the Defence Housing Authority and I understand it is already up to about $13m. I have a copy of the appropriations of the Department of Defence. They show an additional estimate of $9.124m, but do not show any detail about an interest supplement. I do not see how it can be proved that the Government has provided $13m extra. Quite apart from that, at the end of the 10-year period is that $750m returnable to the Commonwealth or not? How is it intended to fund the supplement, and what is to happen to the loan at the end of the 10-year period?

We are in the ridiculous position of this country having been run down to its knees. It is suffering at every level. Small business people are suffering a rate of 23 per cent on their overdrafts, and I do not know how they can operate in business these days. Families are trying to get homes on 16 per cent to 16.5 per cent mortgages. All of this is due to the mismanagement of the economy by that Minister over there, who likes to scream and yell and not deal with the substance of an argument. To me, with my responsibilities for defence force personel, the impact falls first on the defence budget and, secondly, on the budgets of all those little families, young wives, young husbands and their babies, which this Government sends from one end of the country to the other. The Government is not prepared to give those people proper recompense for their service to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can we do that with your double dipping?
—Those people serve this country with their whole hearts and all they get is a rabble rouser like the Minister opposite. They do not deserve it.
—How can we do these things with double dippers like you sponging on it?

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The Minister cannot reflect on personalities and personal attributes of speakers in this chamber. I ask that the Minister be requested to withdraw.
—Withdraw what?
—The Minister was reflecting on the character of the senator who was on her feet at the time. I find it quite unparliamentary and inpermissible under the Standing Orders.

—I was stating a fact-that Senator Newman's husband is double dipping through the Commonwealth parliamentary pension and the defence forces retirement benefit pension. If Senator Newman were to meet with a fatal accident tomorrow, he would be triple dipping. I find the degree of humbug and hypocrisy in Senator Newman purporting to speak for ordinary defence personnel when her husband is a double dipper and has the possibility of becoming a triple dipper rather offensive. However, if Senator MacGibbon believes I am reflecting personally on Senator Newman in doing so, I am quite happy to withdraw.

—I am very interested that the Minister is prepared to try this stunt on again. He tries it about once a year. I would also like to have it on the record that my husband served his country and fought for his country in Vietnam, which is more than the Minister did. My husband contributed to any pension that he has earned and he has served this country long and hard. If the Minister does not like the system, he has been in government for six years and he could change the law. If he believes that wives who work should not be entitled to their husband's pension if they survive their husbands, let him tell the women employed in the Public Service that they are not to inherit their husband's pension if the husband is also on the Commonwealth payroll. If that is what the Minister intends, let him announce it and let him change the law. He would not dare. I challenge the Minister; I challenge him to change the law.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to the fact that this Government does not give a dash about the defence forces of this country.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The position is becoming intolerable, where allegations of lying and fibs are made. The word `bludger' was used a little while earlier about the spouse of the honourable senator. If we are going to carry on in this way we ought be look at one of Senator Walsh's colleagues, Mr Duncan, who I believe really got into the jackpot on superannuation.
—Senator MacGibbon, I do not think that is relevant to the point of order.

—Briefly, in concluding, because the Minister is trying to take from the time I have left, this Government cannot provide sufficient funds to feed our troops properly. If you remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, last year I brought it to the attention of the Senate that there was a $3.1m shortfall in rations for the troops. This year and next year there is a $28m shortfall in clothing for the troops. That is what a good manager this Government is! That is how much it cares for the people it sends to defend this country. Yet, it struts the world stage telling the world, `We will send a brigade to Kampuchea; we will send engineers to Namibia; we will send somebody to Vanuatu and we will send some more to Fiji'. Government members are great ones for making big fellows of themselves overseas, but they will not feed and clothe the troops properly back home in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh can sling all the mud that he likes. If he does not like the kitchen, he can get out. When it comes to the defence of this country your record is rotten, rotten and rotten. The defence forces of Australia know that you are no good and your golden boy, Dr Strangelove, is no good either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Newman, will you address your remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President. I quite forgot you were there for the moment. I was so busy making sure that I taught this Minister a lesson. If the Minister is so interested in the fine print of accounting, let him see that his own Government does a much better job of accounting with the nation's resources, because this Government is a rotten manager of the national Budget and an even worse manager of the defence Budget. If it were a better manager, we would be able to achieve more with the scarce resources we have. But it is failing on every level. If the Minister for Defence got cleaned out in the next election and we got into government, we would show those opposite how to make the defence dollars go further and defend Australia better. The Government has a lot of lessons to learn and at the very next election the people of Australia, including all those Defence Force families which have been neglected, will show the Government there is a better way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not help thinking earlier this evening when Senator Crowley was speaking what a pity it is that we have a government in this country that tends to look at families in terms of hand-outs and assistance. Surely that is necessary for a number of them, but would it not be much better if we had a government that looked at creating an economic situation whereby families were able to earn enough money to support themselves, to make the decisions that they want to make for themselves, and not merely at increasing hand-outs and assistance? Senator Crowley also referred to the Government having honoured its commitment in relation to child poverty. I remember that in April of this year, when certain increases were announced by the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said the Government had honoured its commitment. He gave no evidence whatever to support that fact, but he certainly did not convince everybody that that was the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Canberra Times report on 19 May of the speech given by the Anglican Bishop of Canberra and Goulburn, the Right Reverend Owen Dowling, when he was speaking at the launch of this year's Bishop's Welfare Appeal, which has a target for this diocese of $150,000. I quote:

Poverty in Australia has not lessened, despite the Prime Minister's pledge that no child need live in poverty after 1991, according to the Anglican Bishop of Canberra and Goulburn, the Right Reverend Own Dowling . . .
He said the Prime Minister's pledge stretched his credulity.
`I would like to believe it to be true but I suspect the poverty element in our society has not actually reduced'.
The bishop said:

. . . there had been some relief but many people from the middle-income group were not making it. It had been estimated that one in five families in Australia were below the poverty line, therefore the number of children involved in poverty was much higher than 20 per cent.

I think the bishop knows what he is talking about. All the words of the Prime Minister when he said that he would honour his commitment will not convince those who still have serious financial problems in making ends meet for their families. They will not be convinced that because the Prime Minister says so it is right.

The Appropriation and Supply Bills that we are discussing today relate to the authorisation by the Parliament of several hundred millions of dollars from Consolidated Revenue for the purpose of government expenditure. They cover many areas and a number of honourable senators have spoken about matters in which they have a concern. It is reasonable that we look closely at this expenditure and where the Government gets the money from. The lion's share comes from pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers, ordinary workers and their families, in this country.

It is worth remembering that the Government has no money of its own and cannot have money of its own; it can only have what it takes from the people of this country. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) said earlier this month that PAYE tax collections in the nine months ended March of this year totalled $30,147m, almost 17 per cent up on collections for the same period a year earlier. Let us remember, of course, that this Government boasts about keeping wages down. When one looks at the fact that the PAYE collections are up 17 per cent, one realises exactly how much more is being taken from the wage earners of this country. Company tax was up 13.6 per cent; sales tax was up 24 per cent. It is indeed a high taxing government which finds many and devious ways of collecting more money from the people of this country.

In the current financial year so far, Government revenue is up by 7.7 per cent compared with the previous year. The Minister explained that the increased PAYE collections arose, in part, from increased employment. Nobody argues that there has been some increased employment, but that is only a partial explanation for the extra amount which has been collected. While earning a little more, people find that each time they are paying a great deal more in taxation. This is expressed as `bracket creep'. It is of course not surprising that the Government does not say too much about that, but Australian workers know that they are paying a great deal more in taxation than they ever have before. They are no longer interested in working overtime. It just is not worth their time and trouble because of the amount of money that the Government takes from them. The Government cannot ignore the fact that its tax policies have led wage and salary earners to the conclusions that the harder they work the more the Government will take from them.

The Government should not fool itself that it can convince the public that the tax cuts announced recently will make up for what they have lost over the last six years. There was, I am sure everybody would agree, a very cynical reception to the tax package announced in April of this year. The taxpayers of this country are not gullible. They know what has happened and the bribe, or the attempted bribe, will not work. They will not accept the short term palliative of a tax cut just prior to an election and feel that they are supposed to be grateful as a consequence of what they are receiving.

They want solutions to the larger fundamental problems with the economy which have resulted in the high inflation and high interest rates they face. Interest rates, already at record levels, are, from everything I have read lately by the experts, looking very certain to rise again. This is killing the dream of home ownership for Australian families. An article in the editorial column of the Canberra Times of 22 May carried the headline `Interest should go no higher.' The article stated:
With the majority of mortgages now over $80,000, the increase in interest rates is dragging an extra $100 a month from the pockets of borrowers. Many, of course, cannot afford it.

Those out there who are having to sell homes because they cannot afford the repayments know exactly that. People will find that their homes have a mortgage and a debt upon them which are more than they will be able to sell them for. They have no hope of ever owning their own home because of the debt. If they rewrite the mortgage so that the payments remain lower as interest rates go up, the end result is quite devastating considering what they will owe in mortgage and interest payments in the longer term. So far this financial year, the cost has risen $40 a week. A New South Wales family with an average mortgage of $84,000 is paying over $270 a week in repayments. Most families would be far better off swapping tax cuts for lower interest rates. Labor has deliberately chosen higher interest rates as its major economic policy weapon in dealing with our balance of payments and inflation crisis. It appears from what the Government says that there will not be any change.

Those who are hurting are the people who have entered into contracts and are attempting to purchase their homes. They are facing enormous monthly repayments, frequently far beyond their earning capacity. According to affordability surveys based on 25 per cent of family income being an appropriate amount to be paying for the purchase of a house, the only families that can buy an average home and meet the repayments at present would need an income of more than $65,000 a year, and that is more than double the average Australian family income. That is the position we have reached after six years of Labor's economic management.

The consequence of this is that it places families under enormous pressure. A marriage guidance council confirms that the number of people seeking guidance owing to the housing crisis is putting a strain on its resources. Soaring house prices and interest rates have taken a very heavy toll of families in this country. Many young couples attempting to buy a home have put off starting a family for many years. They are starting a family much later in life; some are not having a family at all. Ordinary men and women around this country are telling the Government by whatever means are at their disposal-by writing to the papers and by writing to their members and senators-that they cannot take these high interest rates, that they cannot continue.

People have been protesting in rallies around the country. In Canberra, the interest rates revolt group has been formed. Mrs Jeffreys and others have banded together to try to get the message across to the Government. These people are not attempting to buy luxuries, to have holidays or to go out or entertain; they merely want to be able to meet their financial commitments and provide accommodation for their families. They want to be able to feed their families. However, many can no longer afford to buy new clothing for their children.

I have had a number of letters from people in my electorate. One has come from a married mother of two, who survives on the single income of her husband. She says that she believes that he is on a good wage and that the only debt the family has is a mortgage. She is certainly not able to buy clothes for herself. She worries about the family car breaking down because they do not have money available to repair it. The family finds it impossible to save and they have to live without the security of anything put aside in case of emergencies.

Another married woman with two children contacted me. She can no longer afford to buy clothes; she has had to cut back on the amount she spends on food; and going out, and any form of entertainment, is absolutely out of the question. She faces the problem that if any of her household appliances breaks down she has no hope of finding the money for repairs. These people are not complaining about missing out on any of life's little luxuries. They are talking about providing adequate food and clothing for their children, maintaining the family vehicle which is probably getting on in years and being able to maintain household appliances. These are not isolated accounts and this is reflected throughout this country.
I wish to read some parts of one letter I received because I think it is worth reading. The writer asked:
I wonder if Mr Keating and Mr Hawke really know what it is like to try to meet the everyday needs of a family;-
I interpose to say that that is a very fair question-

To have to empty money boxes several days before payday to be able to buy petrol; to run out of butter or margarine and literally have unbuttered sandwiches and toast; to go to a doctor, get a script, then reassess the gravity of the complaint and decide that salt water gargles for another 24 hours may avert the need for the antibiotic, or if it's a skin complaint, put up with it; to buy a child's sneakers from St Vinnies and make him wear them with thick socks because it is impossible to contemplate the purchase of a new and better fitting pair; to go without dental checkups and treatment because there just isn't any money for a dentist's visit; to make a child put up with badly scratched glasses; telling a child he or she can not play a sport or join Scouts because they have to be classed as extras. One doesn't even need to have a very large family for these to occur.

As the writer indicates, these are not isolated instances. If honourable senators go out into their electorates and into the community they will find that this is more and more the case. The writer continued:
It is situations of this type that cause people to use bankcards, borrow and end up in debt. It is not necessarily the purchasing of luxury items on credit.

It is situations such as the one she describes that force mothers who wish to be at home with their children for a period to go out into the work force, and that creates other problems and stresses for families. The author of this letter, like many others, accepts and makes it plain that, in times of economic difficulties, sacrifices must be made. That is accepted in the community but it is the middle income families that are sacrificing so much. The letter continued:

When the country's economy is tight it is right and fitting that every one should be required to tighten one's belt and contribute to righting the situation but this should be required of all sectors of the community; big business, corporate sectors, workers, self-employed.

I don't agree with the idea of taking from the rich and giving to the poor but surely there are ways and means of putting some form of incentives into the system to encourage people to work and enable them to see the results of their work: ie to be able to meet their basic needs, improve their standard of living, getting satisfaction from the fact that what they have is a result of their productivity.
When a man works an extra shift and gives extra time to help his boss he is penalised by our current tax system.
That statement is worth repeating:
When a man works an extra shift and gives extra time to help his boss he is penalised by our current tax system.
All she is asking for really is a fair go. What the Government is offering wage and salary earners and their families is nothing but discouragement. I will read the concluding portion of that letter:

Let's face it. It's the groups that can make the loudest noise who get attention. Families don't complain, grumble, strike etc, because they are just too busy getting on with their lives with all the demands, emotional or otherwise, that are placed on them. Surely, if the Government really has this country's future welfare at heart it would concentrate on the area which is the backbone of any nation, and that is the family.

I would echo that and say that I hope that the Government will listen and will pursue policies to enable families to do what they want to do for themselves without taxation being at the level at which it has been.

Of course, as is mentioned in the letter, there is the matter of personal debt. The figures disclosed in February this year showed that every Australian man, woman and child owed more than $2,500 each in personal debt, that is, $5,100 for every member of the work force-a national total of $41.8 billion. It is clear that ordinary people are being forced into taking on this sort of debt merely to maintain their families. The Government is attempting to ignore the implications of this development. The Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, is quoted as saying that the new figures added `some urgency' to the problem of high personal debt but that the Government would not change its approach to it. It is the same `do nothing' approach that it takes with interest rates.

The Government can be blase about the problem of consumer debt, but others are not. The Economic Planning Advisory Council warned in April that at least 100,000 Australian families were struggling to pay off their consumer debts. Of course, do not forget that for the most part that debt attracts an interest rate of about 23 per cent. The fundamental cause of this enormous increase in personal debt, which means a fall in the standard of living under Labor, is increased interest rates, high inflation and high taxation. Notwithstanding the recently announced tax cuts, the Government should be clear that many Australians do not accept that the taxation system is in any way fair or equitable. Another letter that I received, referring to this matter and its impact on working people, said:
Every person in the mid to lower income tax bracket acknowledges that they are easy picking.

That letter, which was written by a young woman with four children, described the cycle in which she had found herself. I have spoken to many in this situation. She is divorced, her marriage having broken up for one reason or another. She wants to get ahead and provide a healthy outlook on life for her children. She wants to secure a position and a future for herself. She wants to be able to capitalise on her future. She needs to obtain a tertiary education. To do this, she needs money for baby-sitters, education costs and the fees she will have to pay. She may not find it very easy to get time off work to study. To get the money required means working extra hard to achieve bonuses or even taking a second job. She would then be in a higher tax bracket which penalises such initiatives and compels the woman to stay poor, uneducated and futureless. I have spoken to many in that situation who find that they are better off remaining on the supporting parents benefit than risk attempting to get ahead and who feel that if they lose the benefits that go with it they will not be able to get the medication they would need if their child became sick. It is a tragic situation. I quote from that letter:

What happens in the minds of Australia's greatest resource when they see incentive stifled at every turn. That is glaringly obvious, isn't it-a youth unemployment rate of 20 per cent and kids that cannot be bothered trying any more. It is becoming apparent to myself that the strategy of this Government is to keep working class people poor, keep them ignorant, and keep them down. People are so busy just trying to exist that they haven't got time to question, let alone raise a fuss about the real people ripping off the system.

That is common. I have quoted from a few letters tonight-I have received many others-because people can better express in their own words what they really feel about the situation in which they find themselves at present as they struggle to keep their heads above water. They find it impossible to save anything or put anything aside for emergencies and certainly experience grave difficulty in buying or making payments on a home for themselves and their families.

People want to be able to work, and work hard, and be able to reap the rewards that flow from it. They want a reasonable standard of living so that they can provide for their children. They want to get the benefit from improved productivity. They want to be able to make decisions for their families and themselves. Unfortunately, the Government seems unwilling to make any genuine attempts to reform the wages system and put in place a taxation system which will enable that to occur. Thousands of Australian workers and their families cannot look forward to an improved standard of living until such fundamental problems are dealt with. Let us not forget the extent to which their standard of living has dropped in the six years in which Labor has been in government. Labor's answer to the economic ills is inadequate tax cuts, high interest and high inflation. The only thing that will really help people in this country is for a Liberal government to be elected. While this Government remains in power, I hope it will address at least some of the problems that are facing families in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Appropriation Bills. In doing so, what strikes me most about the Bills is the extraordinary priorities that this Government has in many areas. It does not seem to have any idea that the country has to generate sources of income if we are to survive. It does not seem to understand that the fluctuation in the value of the dollar has added $10 billion to $15 billion to Australia's overseas debt in the last two or three weeks. It does not seem to understand that if there is a $2 billion deficit for May, as has been predicted, the interest alone on that amount is in the order of $150m a year. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber, may understand that $150m a year is about as much as we get for the total of Australia's woodchip exports. The total of Australia's woodchip exports will pay one month's interest on the extra deficit, and that is all.

SPEECH.PARA: We are bleeding to death from interest payments. But the world's worst Treasurer does not seem to believe there is any problem about that. He does not seem to take it seriously. He says, `We are on course' and leaves it at that. People around Australia can no longer tolerate it being left at that. We have to build up the country's generating operations. We have to face this question of interest. We are paying the highest rate of interest of any similar country in the world. Our debt is now at the level of those countries that we have been led to believe are in a very poor state. We are in the same order as Brazil and Mexico. I would not have thought that this would bring the Treasurer (Mr Keating) any great joy. I was interested to read a portion of a speech given by Sir Arvi Parbo on 5 May in Melbourne. In one paragraph he said:

In June 1980 our net overseas debt was 6.3% of GDP-that is 6.3 per cent of what we produce annually. By June 1985 it had leapt to 25% and is now over 30% of GDP. In these terms it has risen by five times in less than a decade. In money terms we have gone up fourteen times from a debt of about $7 billion to what will be around $100 billion by the middle of this year. (The gross debt is well over $100 billion). The debt is increasing at the rate of $50 million a day. During the hour and a half we are spending at this lunch, it will have increased by $3 million.

The world's worst Treasurer does not seem at any stage to take that into account. He says that we are still on track. It is a pretty poor track we are on, and I do not know where it will wind up. The people of Australia must change this wretched Government and get a bit of financial management from people who know where they are going, who know when things are serious and who are prepared to do something about it. That is the only alternative. The Government has said that it supports higher wages. The people of Australia certainly need them, but higher wages have to be accompanied by higher productivity. I notice that we are now using various newfangled expressions for covering up on a wages increase that means absolutely nothing and produces absolutely nothing except greater debts and higher interest. We are still going up this track of having higher interest rates and greater and greater debt.

Senator Reid covered many of the domestic issues very well and clearly demonstrated the sorts of problems that the average people are suffering from. But it goes a lot further than that, because over the last 12 months the arrears owing through the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation have gone up again by another 7.1 per cent. This debt concerns people's greatest asset-their house. It has risen another 7.1 per cent over the very high figure that applied before. The world's worst Treasurer does not worry about that either-I do not know whether he even recognises it-but the people whose houses are in jeopardy, the people who may lose the roof over their heads, certainly understand.

Let us look at the individual areas. Tonight I would like to deal briefly with only three small areas. I would like to mention science, the Antarctic, and foreign fishing. On the matter of science, in the last week or two the newspapers and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have been talking about a $1 billion hand-out for science and research. That is absolutely, flagrantly, deliberately and wantonly incorrect. That so-called $1 billion is, of course, to be allocated over five years; it is not a simple injection of $1 billion that could now well be made if the Government had any intention of trying to generate the economy into productivity again. Approximately two-thirds of the $1 billion goes to tax deductions in the area of research and development in the private sector. That is an increase on the situation that applied before, but in the areas where the Government has the responsibility the position is quite different. Of course, the majority of the money left after that-the $78m per annum average-goes to Mr Dawkins, not to the Department of Science as such. That is important and it needs to be taken into account.

Of that $78m a year, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) may get $18m per year. The Prime Minister has decided that, as he wants to beat up his own position a little, he will take unto himself science, the greenhouse effect and anything else which might provide a bit of good publicity and on which he can shower some money. Of that amount, $7.8m is to go to funding work in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet on the greenhouse effect. Even when Senator Richardson, the muscleman in this organisation, applied for $1m he could not get it. The amount of $1m last year in many respects would have been far more valuable than $7.8m as part of this $1 billion package.

The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation is to get $2.5m over five years. The Australian Institute of Marine Science is to get $2.5m over five years. Marine science generally gets $3.9m, or $0.78m a year. The universities and colleges get $35m a year, and then we have an Australia Prize of a quarter of a million dollars a year. So it goes on. But where will that have an effect? How will that catch up the huge losses accumulated in the last seven years? Every year since this Government has been in office there have been huge cuts in the generator of the Australian economy. Without the work done by science, and without the hope that it gives our young people to work in this country for this country, we are going downhill fast. And it does not worry the world's worst Treasurer one iota.

I give credit to Barry Jones for doing absolutely everything that one man could possibly do to try to get some interest in science-and, or course, he can get interest everywhere except in the Cabinet room. The way he has been treated by the Prime Minister, by Mr Dawkins in particular, and by others is absolutely disgraceful. The dedication of the man in staying in his portfolio deserves particular mention. The derogatory remarks that he suffers at the hands of his colleagues do none of them any credit. If any of them had the dedication to their jobs that he has for his, we in Australia might be in a slightly better state-but they do not and so we are not.

If we are to get this economy moving we will have to get this generator started, and it will not start without fuel. The situation now is that in most of the science places I go to I find people trying to work with equipment that is hopelessly out of date and hopelessly inadequate. We are expecting people to produce for the year 2000 and beyond with the clapped-out equipment of the 1960s and 1970s. Any other country with any desire to succeed in these areas has provided its people with reasonable, adequate equipment for a start. Such countries have also given their people some sense of security and some pride in what they are doing. But here the people engaged in science are underpaid. The qualification necessary to get into science has now been downgraded, and now it is way down the list for the people with high intellectual capacity. We are expecting those people to come up with the best science in the world, and it just does not happen that way. There is no security in their work. People are leaving in considerable numbers. I noticed in the computer section of the Australian of 9 May an article under the heading, `Expatriate researchers argue a number-cruncher of our own is essential now to secure the future'. It then goes on to state, `Brain drain: the super story of why scientists go', and to list several Australians who have done remarkable things in various areas of science-absolutely top men and men of considerable brilliance except that they are all overseas. All the good research they are doing is being done in other places. Why should that be? Twenty years ago Australians led the world in many of these areas. Why do they not now? We have destroyed many of these people. We have killed the incentive and the initiative that they had. Where are we heading?

Let us take the area of marine science. We have a greater area within our 200-mile limit than we have in our land area. What are we doing about research in that area? What do we know about the mangrove areas or the Great Barrier Reef? We have a magnificent research vessel, the Aurora Australis. It looks lovely tied up at the Hobart wharf. It would look a jolly sight better if we provided it with some fuel and let it go to sea. What about research generally? What do we know about the waters and the fish that are in the waters? Precious little. Why? These waters have a lot of very valuable material in them, but we do not do anything about it and we do not let anybody else do anything about it. We have this magnificent boat tied up at the Hobart wharf. When we read newspaper articles on the subject, we find that not one word of credit goes to the Government for what it has done. Every article that I have seen over the months is critical of the Government's performance in this area, and it is not suddenly going to come right unless somebody makes it come right.

It is extraordinary that the Government believes that it can say to the CSIRO, `Go out and get 30 per cent of the money you need and get on with your research'. There are many areas of CSIRO research in which it is just not appropriate to try to raise that sort of money. There are other areas where, if it does raise the money, the money is tied, which reduces the amount of discretionary funds it has for other jobs, and it accordingly winds down on other research. Every tied job it gets reduces the funds available for other areas of research. It is so short-sighted; it is so absolutely stupid. I do not care whether it is the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) or the Prime Minister himself who says that has to be done; what is going on is absolutely stupid. Unless we start this generator we will never improve our position internationally, but it does not seem to matter to the Government that we are going down and down.

I will briefly touch on the Antarctic. It has become clear in the course of the Estimates hearings and as a result of other committee hearings conducted at about the same time that all is not well with the operation of the Antarctic Division. One thing that is clearly not right is that it is in the wrong hands. Why the Antarctic Division should be in the hands of the Minister for odds and ends-for sport, recreation and whatever else-I do not know. It is clearly inappropriate. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) clearly has no interest in it. At one stage he was asked whether he had been to Kingston, south of Hobart. He said yes, he had. We knew very well that he had not, because the people down there were absolutely disgusted at the fact that, while he was trotting backwards and forwards to Tasmania once or twice a week, he had never been to the Antarctic base. Later, when we quizzed him on it a second time, he admitted that he had telephoned the base but he had not been there up to that point. Is it any wonder that morale is low when the Minister deliberately misleads the Senate by giving the wrong information?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There is an allegation that the Minister has deliberately misled the Senate. There is no evidence of that. I suggest that the allegation be withdrawn.

—I withdraw and say that the Minister at one stage said that he had visited the Antarctic base when in fact he had not. Later he admitted that what he had said was wrong. Does that satisfy the Minister? That is in fact what happened. The Minister in fact admitted that he was wrong. I would have thought he would have known whether or not he had been there before.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get onto the question of sledges for the Antarctic. Why we have to build sledges in Germany when we can build the ship that is going to carry the sledges in Australia baffled even the Minister. We clearly need to work this one out. The stupidity of spending money on buying sledges made in Germany which were ordered nine months before they were needed and which, because of the weather conditions, still have not been delivered 14 months later, requires attention. It is a crazy business.

We also have the question of the Lady Franklin. Due to bad management and bad planning, the Lady Franklin was sent to the Antarctic area at the beginning of October last year and, of course, could not get into the base, whereupon it turned around and came back. It was also discovered that some of the gear had been left on the Hobart wharf and it was then necessary to get the Air Force to parachute it onto Macquarie Island. This is the way this enterprise is run. This is Minister Richardson's bailiwick. Again I say that he has no interest in it. Morale is low as a result and management is less than adequate.

I turn to the matter of foreign fishing. We have been told that the main aim of the fishing service is to improve the Australianisation of foreign fishing in these external waters. After a number of questions during the Estimates hearings, we found that in spite of that, and in spite of trying to get Australians involved in one way or another, we had hived off considerable tonnages of the allocation that we were making and let them go to the Republic of China on a straight fee fishing basis. The Chinese paid $336,000 in access fees to fish the North West Shelf, and that was all. They take the fish, pay the money and go. That is not helping the Australian fishing industry one iota. We found in the cut-up of the tonnage that 2,850 tonnes were not allocated. Why they were originally gazetted as being available and then not allocated, I am not sure, except that subsequent correspondence says that they were being held for Australian fishermen.

The fact is that at that time a company was prepared to move in, to build considerable equipment in Australia, to replace its ships with ships built in Australia and to market either inside or outside Australia, whichever was decided. When we raised this during the Estimates hearings we were told that the Government had considered it but it was not appropriate. I have a letter which more or less confirms that in various words. I still cannot understand why this was so, and I am a long way from being satisfied as to why we get this sort of answer. Why should we sell our fish to some foreign country when we could establish a great Australian industry in Western Australia? I am sure that the Western Australian senators would like to know that too. It is another matter which I hope we will be able to deal with later on when we get to the committee stage.

I believe that this Government's extraordinary priorities regarding the income producing areas of the nation as against the non-income producing areas require a lot more attention. I am disgusted at the way the priorities are worked out, and we will deal with that at a future time.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday 15 May 1989 workers at Henderson's Spring Industries in Melbourne ended a 10-day strike. Much has been said about it. My remarks will be short. We live in hard economic times. There is need for restraint, for sacrifice, for altruism. Workers are asked for greater effort for the country's good. Given this, the strike was tagged as unwarranted. Four thousand vehicle builders were stood down, production was slowed and the economy was prejudiced.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did people at Henderson's strike? The reason is found in their work conditions. Last week two employees told me of their experiences with the company before the strike. One employee has worked at Henderson's for the last year. His shift is from 4 o'clock in the afternoon till after midnight and he arrives home each night at about 1.00 a.m. His domestic problems are great; he has a child needing extensive medical treatment; and his wife looks after the child and does not work. Before the strike he took home about $290 a week. This is hardly commensurate with the cost of basic living. Bills for rent, food, clothing, gas, electricity, transport, medication and toiletries mounted up to overwhelm his family. His problems still haunt him both at home and at work. There are very few other places to which he can afford to go.

When he first worked with Henderson's there was overtime. That gave him a reasonable wage. He took home about $370 a week. About three months ago the company instituted a scheme to increase production. It did so. This reduced the need for overtime and his wage fell by $80 net a week. There was limited overtime available for a period following the increase in productivity. This was given to those favoured by management. Those not favoured found their pay slashed. Now overtime is available to a few key workers only.

The other person I spoke to was one of the key workers. He does overtime. He works 9 1/2 hours a day six days a week and at times on Sunday. He must do so in poor conditions. Before the strike he earned $475 a week. He is a family man, he has a wife and two young children; his wife must look after the children and so cannot go out to work. Quite often she needs his help at home but she cannot get it because of the hours he works. This leads to tension and there is misery aplenty.

The Henderson's strike imposed costs on the country, on employer and on employee. This was an unhappy outcome which no-one welcomed. The forces driving the workers were great. Poor pay, bad conditions, long hours and troubled relations with management set the scene for their industrial action. To ignore these realities is to be unfair and foolhardy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.33 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 19 December 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government assisted the Holland Construction Group, based in Perth, and its subsidiary, International Railway Construction, in negotiations with the Malaysian Government to build a railway into the tropical forest area of Sarawak.
(2) For what purpose will this railway be used.

(3) If this railway is to be used for development of open cast coalmines and/or to facilitate the exploitation of timber resources in the region, is the Minister aware that this development will exacerbate the greenhouse effect, contribute to further destruction of primary tropical forests and further destabilise the climatic balance of the region.
(4) Will development of coalmines in Sarawak and other parts of the island of Borneo, contribute further to the global oversupply of coal.
(5) Will coal from these sources compete with Australian production and result in further employment shedding in the Australian coal industry.
(6) Is the Minister aware of the plight of the indigenous people of Sarawak, particularly the Kayan, Kelesit and Penan tribes.

(7) Is the Holland Construction Groups' development likely to lead to further deterioration of the basic human rights and land claims of those peoples by causing further destruction of the forests on which they depend.

(8) Has the Minister's office received inquiries from members of the public expressing concern on this issue; if so, how many inquiries has he received and have these inquiries been acknowledged and answered.
(9) Are timber and timber products from this region imported into Australia.
(10) Will the Minister give an assurance that no timber or timber products will be imported into Australia from this area in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 1 June 1987, the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) provided a list of locations of single-purpose railways constructed within Australia in response to a request by John Holland Holdings. While the information may have been used by the company in preparation of a submission to the Sarawak government, the Australian government has not assisted the company in negotiations in the sense of making any representation to either the Malaysian or Sarawak government on the company's behalf.

(2) I understand the proposed railway is to be used as a logging railway, as part of timber industry development in Sarawak, and the involvement proposed by the John Holland Company is in railway construction only.

(3) I am not prepared to endorse the assumptions made by Senator Dunn concerning the effect of such developments with respect to the greenhouse effect and the climate of the region. Logging of tropical forests does not necessarily increase the greenhouse effect. New growth is a greater net consumer of carbon dioxide than climax forest. The key issue is land use practices after logging. Clearfelling and burning followed by conversion to agricultural land would most likely contribute to the greenhouse effect. However, I understand that control of the exploitation of timber resources is the responsibility of the Sarawak government, which states that logging is carried out under guidelines of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) aimed at sustainable long term yields.

(4) I am not aware of any substantive proposals to develop coal resources in Sarawak. There are significant coal project developments in the planning and implementation stage in Kalimantan, which is Indonesian Territory. The massive expansion in prospect in the Indonesian coal industry is primarily destined for domestic consumption and the surplus available for export is expected to be relatively small. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy's estimate of the amount available for export in 1995 is about 4 million tonnes a year. By definition, these will add to the future world supply of coal; whether this might be deemed an oversupply will depend on demand conditions at the time. Studies the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has undertaken forecast continuing growth in world demand for steaming coal over the next decade.

(5) Coal from these sources may compete with Australian production. Projections of international and regional demand by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy indicate that there is an opportunity for the Australian coal industry to share in future demand growth. Whether these opportunities are realised will depend on the industry's competitiveness with production from new producers and incremental production from existing producers.

(6) I am aware that the population of Sarawak includes a number of distinct tribal groupings. I am also aware that some of these peoples, particularly the Penan, continue to lead a nomadic existence and that it appears the long term policies of the Malaysian Federal and State Governments are for their integration into the broader Malaysian population. Officers of our High Commission in Kuala Lumpur have discussed these issues with relevant State and Federal authorities in the context of the Australian Government's strong support for the observance of internationally accepted standards of human rights. The Government is continuing to monitor these issues closely.

(8) I received 6 written representations in 1988 suggesting Australia should ban imports of products from tropical forests. All have been answered. I have received no written representations on the specific issues raised by Senator Dunn.
(9) Australia imports timber and timber products from Malaysia. Details of whether these are sourced from Sarawak are not available.

(10) Firstly, it is not possible to identify products from logs sourced from Sarawak. Secondly, Australia acceded in February 1988 to the International Tropical Timber Agreement (ITTA) developed under the auspices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). ITTA provides a framework for co-operation and consultation between tropical timber producing and consuming countries. It seeks to promote the development of the tropical timber market, to improve forest management, and to encourage further processing in producing countries. At the same time it encourages the development of national policies aimed at sustainable utilisation of tropical forests, conservation of their genetic resources and maintenance of the ecological balance in the regions concerned. I would also draw Senator Dunn's attention to my announcement of 27 April 1989 that I will be convening shortly a meeting at which Trade Union, Conservation, Timber Industry and State Government representatives could discuss constructive Australian initiatives towards solving the problems caused by deforestation in tropical countries. One idea I have in mind is to raise the question of standards for sustainable management practices and environmental protection in tropical forestry at the next meeting of the International Tropical Timber Organisation in late May.
Against this background, I will not give an assurance of the impractical and inappropriate kind sought by Senator Dunn.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the alleged murder of David Blenkinsop in Indonesia on 14 August 1988 and the attempted slaying of his pregnant girlfriend:
(1) What measures has the Australian Government made to ensure the proceedings will be fair and honest for a trial against an Indonesian policeman to begin on 20 February 1988.
(2) Have diplomatic or other inquiries been made by Australia to ensure Indonesian investigations prior to the trial have been thorough and complete.
(3) In view of some media speculation, is the Australian Government satisfied the right man is in the dock and, if so, that he was the only person involved.

(4) Will the Minister give an assurance that the trial will be totally monitored by the Australian authorities from start to finish, and that the interests of the family of the late Mr Blenkinsop will be safeguarded throughout.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government policy is that it does not intervene in the judicial processes of other countries. The Honourable Member may wish to refer to the Ministerial Statement of 27 April 1988 in the House of Representatives on Australia's consular role. This did not however prevent the Australian Embassy, in the course of normal consular duties, maintaining close contact with the Indonesian authorities from the time we first learnt about the incident. Mr and Mrs Blenkinsop, in accordance with normal consular procedures were provided with a list of lawyers based in Jakarta in the event that they wished to seek legal advice and support.

(2) As stated in (1), the Government does not intervene in the judicial processes of other countries. Nevertheless, during the pre-trial period, and in addition to the regular Embassy contact with the Indonesian authorities already referred to, the matter was raised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, during his discussions with the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Mr Alatas, in October.

(3) The Australian Government has no reason to believe that the policeman charged by the Indonesian Government was the wrong person. The Honourable Member will be aware that a second person, a civilian, was also tried for his involvement in the affair.

(4) An officer of the Australian Embassy, fluent in Indonesian, was present at all sessions of the trial which took place over 20-23 February in a military court at Biak. The trial was open to the media. The Embassy's presence at the trial was to satisfy the Government that due processes of Indonesian law were followed. The Prime Minister indicated that he was satisfied that on all the advice we have received, the trial was conducted in accordance with Indonesian legal processes. He said that while he could understand some feeling on the part of the Blenkinsop family about the length of the sentences, Australia was not in a position to tell other countries how to run their judicial processes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Agreements Implemented by Federal Legislation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which International Conventions, Treaties and Agreements signed by Australia have been implemented by federal legislation since March 1983.
(2) Which International Conventions, Treaties and Agreements signed by Australia have not been implemented by federal legislation since March 1983.
(3) Why have these International Conventions, Treaties and Agreements which Australia has signed since March 1983 not been implemented by federal legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The first column of the following Table A, based on information provided by the Attorney-General's Department, sets out Acts passed by the Federal Parliament since the beginning of 1983 which have expressly implemented the specific international conventions, treaties and agreements (hereafter ``treaties'') listed against them in the second column which has not previously been implemented in Australian law and which required legislation for implementation.

(2) Table B sets out all 183 treaties signed by Australia between the beginning of 1983 and April 1989. All except those 33 marked with an asterisk have entered into force for Australia. Those 16 marked with the letter (A) also appear in Table A as having been implemented expressly by Federal legislation. (See further the answer to question 3.)
(3) Particular treaties signed since the beginning of 1983 may not have been implemented by Acts of Parliament for the following reasons:

(a) Not all treaties need to be implemented by Acts of Parliament as existing laws, federal and State, usually enables effect to be given to the obligations set out in a treaty. It has been the consistent practice of successive federal Governments that Australia never binds itself to a treaty by bringing it into force until existing law (whether Commonwealth or State) enables effect to be given to obligations created by the treaty. Some treaties are given effect by federal regulations, for example, by providing that an existing Act applies in relation to a country with which a treaty has been concluded.

(b) Some of the 33 treaties in Table B which have not entered into force for Australia have been signed subject to ratification or require some other subsequent step by Australia before they enter into force. In such cases, implementing legislation may still have to be introduced or the Government may still be considering whether to ratify.
(c) Some treaties are implemented by the co-ordinated introduction of new legislation by the States.
My Department will send to the honourable Senator's office a copy of a statement that has been prepared on the treaty making process.

(2) Is the Government able to cite any instances where these media representatives have reported on the impact that US agricultural subsidies are having on the overall Australian-US relationship; if so, and in each case, what was the title of the article, whom was it written by and what was the name and date of the publication.

Most of the media representatives travelled to and from Australia courtesy of Qantas. AOIS met accommodation and travel costs in Australia for some of the visitors. Bloody Dishonest (Or an Australian lesson in what free enterprise should mean)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to a press conference given by the President of the Democratic Kampuchea Party, Mr Khieu Samphan, which was reported in the Financial Review on 23 February 1989 and in view of the mass murders in that unfortunate country between 1975 and 1979 under the stewardship of the notorious Pol Pot, what is the Australian Government's attitude toward the Khmer Rouge.
(2) Is the fact that the Khmer Rouge has now decided to admit its past culpability enough to allow it recognition by the Australian Government.
(3) In the event of a Khmer Rouge-dominated Government emerging from the current political impasse, would such a result be diplomatically acceptable to the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government's attitude towards the Khmer Rouge is one of unequivocal opposition to any return to power of Pol Pot and his senior associates in the Khmer Rouge.
(2) As a result of the Government's decision, in January 1988, to abandon the recognition of governments, the question of ``recognising'' the Khmer Rouge does not arise.

(3) The emergence at the end of the settlement process of a Khmer Rouge-dominated government in Cambodia is most unlikely. Indeed, such an outcome has been specifically ruled out by the Khmer Rouge's main supporter, China. It would not be acceptable to the Cambodian people, to Australia and to world opinion generally.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of international conventions, treaties or agreements which the Federal Government is considering signing; if so, what are the specific avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of such international conventions, treaties or agreements; if not, why are there no avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of international conventions, treaties or agreements.

(2) Are there any avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of international conventions, treaties or agreements which the Federal Government has signed; if so, what are the specific avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of such international conventions, treaties and agreements, if not, why are there no avenues of parliamentary review or oversight of international conventions, treaties or agreements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Constitutional power to enter into treaties is one that belongs to the Governor General in Council. The Commonwealth Parliament, in consequence, has no formal function to exercise by way of review or oversight of international conventions, treaties and agreements which the Federal Government is considering signing.

(2) Successive Australian Governments have observed the practice of bringing all treaties to the attention of Parliament. The practice has been to table treaties in both Houses. This is done at most sessions in batches (tablings took place in April and November 1988) and often individually in the case of particularly important treaties about which statements may also be made to Parliament. Where a treaty enters into force by a step subsequent to signature, every effort is made to table the treaty before that step is taken in order to give Parliament the opportunity to express its view on the treaty. Additionally, Parliament is able to consider its attitude to many treaties when that is necessary for other parliamentary functions, such as appropriating moneys for Commonwealth purposes or enacting legislation to give effect to a treaty. This opportunity arises because it has been the consistent practice of Australian Governments that Australia never binds itself to a treaty unless existing law, state or federal, enables effect to be given to the obligations set out in the treaty. It follows that although Parliament has no formal role in reviewing and oversighting treaty action, there exist a number of avenues through which the Parliament is informed of all treaties which the Government has signed and in respect to which the Parliament may express a view on individual treaties.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Australian Customs Service commenced collection of detailed seizure records on 1 January 1983. Accordingly detailed records are unavailable for the fiscal year 1982-83.

The data available is dependent on information gathered at the time of seizure and after the arrest of offenders. Australian Customs Service major seizures (i.e. those of 1 kilogram and above) for the periods outlined above and the results are listed below.

(3) No Federal or State agency is in a position to provide this information.

(4) The Government does not consider that staffing levels at air and seaports are inadequate to control drug smuggling. The Australian Customs Service (ACS) within the limits of budgetary requirements has deployed its staff with particular emphasis on targetting critical areas. The redeployment of some staff has been made possible by implementing changes in work practices, adopting new technology and generally improving operating procedures.

This, in conjunction with the increased co-operation and intelligence sharing with other enforcement agencies, aims to result in the ACS being even more effective in areas of drug surveillance. Examples of specific measures follow.

The ACS has introduced Contraband Enforcement Teams-mobile Customs teams used to detect unlawful activity, in particular narcotics-related offences. Officers concentrate on high risk areas, ships and cargo instead of being constrained by routine processing work.

The ACS is developing an automated cargo system for officers to risk rate imported cargo, improve cargo flow and simplify accounting. This is in line with the management strategy to develop and apply risk assessment techniques with a view to cost effective deployment of resources while maintaining an appropriate level of protection for the Australian community against the importation of narcotics.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With respect to an article in the Melbourne Age of 17 March 1989 stating that the Federal Government's plans to reorganise its defence operations under a corporation `have stalled' following a breakdown in negotiations with unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) over award conditions, will the newly created Australian Defence Industries Corporation be bound to agree to the commitment apparently given by the Government to the ACTU in 1988 to support the spread of industry-base superannuation.
(2) How long will the official transfer of defence industries to the new corporation be delayed.

(3) Have defence industries/factories being moved to the new corporation been informed of the delay in transfer from the Government under the new Defence industries arrangements; if so, when and how were these defence establishments informed of the delay of the new arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd is a Government owned company which has been established to take over the operations of the Government's defence production facilities. As a separate legal entity from the Commonwealth it will not be bound by the superannuation commitments of the Australian Public Service.

The Company has approval to establish its own superannuation scheme and, subject to approval by the Minister for Finance, will be free to seek a cost effective scheme which will attract a suitable workforce. As a large manufacturing organisation it is reasonable to expect that the Company will consider appropriate industry based schemes.
(2) The defence production facilities were officially transferred to Australian Defence Industries on 3 May 1989.

(3) The production facilities taken over by Australian Defence Industries were in constant contact with the team organising the transition to the Company. The factories were advised on 15 March 1989 of the intention to formally transfer the organisation on 1 May 1989. In the event the transfer was set to take effect from 3 May 1989.
